Ottawa, October 11th, 1894.

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Parry Sound
15th Nov. 1875

Haytin Reed Esq.
Dept. Sup't Genl. of Indian Affairs

Sir,

I regret to have to report that David Chadwick, teacher of the Henry Bullit Indian School informs me that owing to ill health he was compelled on the 31st Oct. to resign and leave his school. He reports having taught till the 31st Oct.

I understand from independent sources that he is apparently labouring under some pulmonary complaint and therefore recommend that his abrupt termination of his engagement be allowed and that I be permitted to forward to your Dept. a requisition for his salary for October.

Meanwhile the school is closed and I request authority to engage a teacher to fill the vacancy. In doing so I anticipate considerable difficulty.

I have the honor to be

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Indian Sup't
Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 13th instant reporting the resignation of Mr David Craddock, teacher of the Henry Inlet School on account of ill-health; and in reply I beg to say that the time for which payment is claimed by the late teacher should be shown on a Return accompanied by a Requisition when the Cheque will be sent you.

You are authorized to obtain the services of a duly qualified teacher as successor to Mr Craddock.

Your obedient servant,

Hawtor Reed Esq.,

Deputy Supt. General of Indian Affairs,

Sir,

Referring to your letter, addressed to me,
dated 18th Nov.-last, File No. 674, 571, informing me
that the salary of Mr. D. Chaddock, late teacher of
the Henvey Mills School, who had been suddenly com-
pelled to resign on account of ill-health, would be
paid for the month of October on the making of
a proper return. I beg to enclose the return required
and the relative requisition.

Mr. Chaddock informs me that he has now
quite recovered and expects to resume his
school next spring. I have informed him that if
he will resume at the New Year, I will engage
him; but that otherwise I should engage the
first suitable applicant. I may add that so
far I have not been able to obtain a teacher
for this school.

I have the honor to be

Your obedient servant,

Pov. H. Wallis,
Indian Supt.
OTTAWA 13th December 1895

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 5th instant relative to payment for the current quarter to the teacher of the Henvey Inlet School; and in reply I beg to say that a cheque for the sum of $20.83 will be sent you for Mr Craddock in payment for the month of October during which he taught school.

The Department approves of your action in informing Mr Craddock that he would be re-engaged provided he could resume his duties at the beginning of the New Year, but that otherwise you would engage another teacher. There should be no delay in opening the school after the Christmas holidays, and if Mr Craddock cannot resume teaching, you should at once take steps to procure another teacher.

Your obedient servant,

Acting Deputy Supt:Genl:

Thos: Walton, Esq:

Dear Sir,

Mr. A. R. Jackson who was engaged to teach the Indian School at Kenway Lake, went up to the Reserve; but when he saw the place & people, he returned home immediately and refused to teach there.

I called at Perry's house to see Mr. McLean the Indian Agent, but found he had gone to Nipissing District on business with the Indians and would not be home for nearly two weeks. In this crisis of affairs I thought it my duty to act.

I therefore secured a
Young man, Mr. Arthur Pearce, who holds a Professional 3rd Class certificate, & has experience in teaching, to take charge of the school at once.

Please acknowledge receipt of these documents, and let me know if you approve of my action in the premises.

Communicate further with Mr. W. W. Lean, Indian Agent.

Sept. 2nd, 1897

I am Yours very truly,

Geo. Grant

P.S. I shall wire Mr. Pearce to start for Newry Gulf, as soon as I get your approval of the transaction.
OTTAWA 1st September 1897

Rev: Sir,

I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 25th ultimo advising the Department that Mr A.R. Jackson, who was engaged to teach the Harvey Inlet school had changed his mind and declined to teach there, and recommended that Mr Arthur Pearce be engaged to replace him. In reply I beg to say that the Department is grateful for the trouble taken by you in this matter in the absence of Mr Superintendent McLean, and approves of the appointment of Mr Pearce to this position. His Certificate is quite satisfactory and is returned herewith having been entered upon the books of the Department. Kindly advise Mr Pearce that the Department would like him to re-open school with as little delay as possible.

Your obedient servant,

J.D. McLEAN
Secretary

Rev: Geo Grant, B.A.,

OTTAWA 1st September 1897

Sir,

I have to inform you that during your absence at Nipissing, the Department has been advised by Mr School Inspector Grant that Mr Jackson who had been engaged to teach the Henvey Inlet Indian school had changed his mind and refused to take charge. Mr Grant recommended that Mr Arthur Pearce, a fully qualified teacher holding a Third Class Certificate be engaged to take his place, and the Department has approved of this appointment and asked Mr Grant to advise him that it would like the school re-opened with as little delay as possible.

Your obedient servant,

J.D. McLean
Secretary

Sir,

I beg to notify the Department that Arthur Beaver, teacher of the Kinney Inlet School, left the school on Sept 30th without giving any notice. This information was only given me today. I have communicated with M. School Inspector Grant for the purpose of securing another teacher to take charge of the school at once.

It seems to be a very difficult matter to get suitable teachers who will remain for any length of time at this outlying school.

I have the honor to be

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

W.B. Maclean
Indian Dept
Sir,

I beg to notify the Department that I have secured the services of Miss Adda McIntosh as teacher of the Kinway Inlet School where instructions her to proceed to the Inlet at once.

As the school has now been closed for over a month I considered it advisable to engage Miss McIntosh at once & trust my action meet with the approval of the Department.

Miss McIntosh is the holder of a third class certificate which I herewith enclose for the purpose of registration.

Yours the honor to be

Sir,

Your obedient servant

W.B. Maclean
Indian Dept.

Miss McIntosh's Certificate is returned herewith, having been duly entered upon the books of the Department.

Sir,

I regret to inform you that Miss Adda McIntosh has been compelled to resign her position as teacher in charge of the Kenway Inlet School on account of illness.

I have today written Mr. School Inspector Grant asking him if he knows of anyone who will undertake to go to Kenway Inlet and open the school. I have also interviewed the Principal of the high school here requesting him to kindly notify me if he can furnish a teacher suitable for the position.

It is most unfortunate that Miss McIntosh has been compelled to resign at this season of the year as I fear it will be most difficult to secure a teacher who will undertake to go to Kenway Inlet until the weather moderates; however, I shall hope that Mr. Inspector Grant will be able to find someone who will accept the position as I am anxious to have the school reopened with as little delay as possible.

As soon as I have received a reply from Mr. Grant I will advise you further in this matter.

Your obedient servant,

W.M. Maclean
Indian Agent
Sir,

I beg to inform you that I have succeeded in securing a teacher to take charge of the Kenny Inlet School in the person of Mr. J.H. Quinn of Parry Sound. Mr. Quinn left here for Kenny Inlet on Friday the 16th inst., and I am now awaiting word from him stating that he arrived safely at the Reserve where he opened the school.

Mr. Quinn is the holder of a third-class certificate which I will forward for your approval as soon as I receive it from him.

Your obedient servant,

W.B. Maclean
Indian Dept.
I beg to enclose you herewith third class certificate of Herbert P. Quinn the teacher engaged to take charge of the Kenway Inlet School, which I forward for the purpose of registration & approval.

OTTAWA, 9th March, 1900

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 6th with enclosure; and in reply I beg to return herewith the certificate of Mr Herbert F. Quinn, whose appointment to take charge of the Hanvey Inlet school is approved of.

Your obedient servant,

S. STEWART

Indian Supt.
Parry Sound,
Ont.
Sir,

I beg to inform you that the Henvey Inlet School has been closed since the beginning of the month owing to the following reason: Mr. H.P. Quinn who re-opened the school after the summer holidays resigned on Sept 30th. I engaged Mr. A.M. Scott to take charge from Oct 1st until the end of the year. Mr. Scott went to Henvey Inlet arriving there on the 3rd inst but would not remain because there was no house for him to live in, so he refused to board with the Indians until the teacher's house, which is being built, was completed.

Mr. Scott returns to Parry Sound on the 10th inst. I at once wrote Miss Ada McIntosh who was formerly in charge of the school offering her the position. In a communication just received from her she has accepted my offer and will re-open the school at the beginning of the week.

I may say that now as the teacher's house is being completed I do not anticipate any trouble in the future in keeping teachers at Henvey Inlet.

Your obedient servant,

W.B. Maclean
Indian Dept
OTTAWA, 2nd November, 1900.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 25th ultimo in reference to the difficulty of obtaining a teacher for the Henvey Inlet school; and in reply I beg to say that your action in engaging Miss McIntosh, the former teacher, to re-open the school as soon as possible, is approved of.

Your obedient servant,

S. STEWART

Asst. Secretary

W.B. Maclean, Esq.
Indian Supt.,
Parry Sound, Ont.
Sir,

I beg to inform you that I have received a letter from Miss Ada McIntosh teacher of the Henvey Inlet School notifying me that she has been compelled to leave the school for a time owing to the serious illness of her mother who resides at Meaford. Miss McIntosh states that she hopes to return to re-open the school before Christmas. In the meantime the school will be closed, as it will be impossible to secure another teacher to go to Henvey Inlet temporarily to take charge.

I shall write Miss McIntosh urging her to return to Henvey Inlet at the earliest possible moment.

Your obedient servant

W.B. Maclean
Indian Dept.

Parry Sound Oct 10th 1905

The Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Sir:

I beg to enclose you herewith letter received from Mr. W. Jones, the teacher recently appointed to succeed Miss Adda McIntosh at the Henvey Inlet Indian School, which refers to matters generally at this school.

In Mr. Jones' letter he makes a request for an advance of one quarter salary ($75.00) stating that he is without supplies or money, so that his request is urgent.

I am aware that such a request is unusual, but owing to the extreme difficulty experienced in securing teachers for such an out of the way place as Henvey Inlet, I believe it is advisable to meet Mr. Jones' request as far as possible, as he is a bright & capable young man, & I desire to retain him at Henvey Inlet & therefore beg to request that your Department will advance him one month's salary or $75.00 as soon as possible.

Your obedient servant,

W.B. Maclean
Indian Agent

Sir:-

I beg to inform you that Mr. W. Jones, teacher of the Henvey Inlet Indian School, has resigned his position and left the school without having given me any previous notice of his intention to do so. I will at once endeavor to secure a new teacher for this school, but owing to the lateness of the season I believe it will be difficult to secure one to re-open this school for the balance of the present term. If I succeed in securing one I will duly notify you.

Your obedient Servant,

Indian Supt.
Ottawa, May 14, 1866.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 11th inst., reporting the resignation of Mr. W. Jones, teacher of the Henvey Inlet school, and in reply I beg to say that his resignation has not yet reached the Department, but you are hereby authorized to engage a successor for the balance of the present quarter. If you are successful in securing the services of a temporary teacher, the question of permanent appointment will receive consideration on the receipt of recommendations and qualifications.

In future it would be well when engaging teachers to have some definite understanding as to their term of service, as the Department considers that it is entitled to due notice before accepting the resignation of a teacher; not less than a month's notice will be taken. If they throw up the position, as in this case, the salary will be withheld for that length of time.

Your obedient Servant,

[Signature]

Secretary.

W. B. Maclean, Esq.,
Indian Superintendent,
Parry Sound, Ont.
MEMO

Sir,

I beg leave to inform you that when I was at Henry Inlet on the 31st of January, I learned that the Chief and Councilors had engaged a School Teacher in the person of Joseph Dillwood, a member of Cape Croker Band, at the same salary as his predecessor. I met Mr. Dillwood. He is a bright, active young Scotch Half-breed. He informed me that his wife died about two weeks ago, leaving a baby about six months old. Who is came for by a Mrs. Cooper, a member of Henry Inlet Band. Mr. Dillwood says he never taught school and has no certificate. Sir,

I beg to make report on above and other correspondence re S.K. Richie who has been teaching school at Henry Inlet.

This man is an Indian half breed and is a cripple having both feet turned in, (club feet). He has some education and puts in most of his time advising the Indians in Indian law etc., and doing considerable correspondence especially with the kickers. He made himself very busy during the war by going around the several reserves collecting money and advising the young Indians not to join up, the result being, very few joining from this agency.

After the war Richie settled on Parry Island and got into trouble and was charged with seducing a young Indian girl and was in Police Court but it was not proven and so he got off after being in jail sometime. Parry Island Indians run him off the reserve. He then drifted to Henry Inlet and the next I heard of him was that he had opened the school at Henry Inlet. I was not aware of it until June last when I received a letter from the Department. I was at Henry Inlet paying Robinson Treaty and expected to see him but he kept out of my way, as he was well aware I could not and would not recommend him as a teacher.
Sir,

However I made some enquiries and found that he had some five or six pupils and the Indians thought he was doing fairly well. I expected they were going to pay him themselves and thought I would leave him alone as long as he behaved himself.

I have never seen him until two weeks ago, he came into my office and said he wished to have me send in his report. I read the Dept. letter 22-2-1 to him and gave him a set of returns papers and asked him to make them out, giving all the information and I would send them to the Department. I received these papers from him on Saturday eve the 29th. of April with a long letter claiming to be paid at the rate of $700.00 per annum.

I might say that I have not recognized him in any way as a teacher but when I was paying at Pickeril on April 26th. last month I took occasion to bring the matter before the Band and they were in favor of paying him $200 in full for his teaching while at Henry Inlet as they say he was not more than four months altogether.

K. Ritchie, as Teacher of the Henvey Inlet Indian Day School. You will remember that you enclosed minutes from the Council meeting, recommending, (1) that a salary of $700.00 per year be paid to Mr. Ritchie; (2) that he be paid $365.45-5/11 for his activity from April 19, 1921 to June 30, 1921; (3) that Mr. Ritchie be retained as teacher for the term commencing September 1, 1921—all of which resolutions were not signed by the Indian agent.

I have now to inform you that the Department has learned, from several sources, that Mr. Ritchie is not the type of teacher that we desire for our Indian schools. However, as he may have acted in good faith, considering he was hired by the Band, this Department is prepared to pay him for his services from April 19 to June 30, 1921, and from September 1, to December 31, 1921, the sum of $365.45-5/11. This money will be taken from the Band funds voted by the Council meeting held on June 10, 1921 ($365.45-5/11) and April 26, 1922 ($200.00). I am sending to Mr. Agent Logan the first mentioned resolution of the Council, and I am asking him to give it his approval if he believes the payment is in order.

I wish to inform you that the Department of Indian Affairs is willing to meet the expenses in connection with the education of the Indian children of the Henvey Inlet Reserve. This will be done from the vote for Indian Education; but you should understand clearly that we will hire the teacher and give him, or her, all instructions. If you and the members of the Band are interested in the education of your children, you will, in turn, do your share by keeping up the attendance.

As mentioned above, $365.45-5/11 will be taken from Band funds as you, as a council, hired the teacher without the approval of the Department and as you have voted this amount. In the future, however, the expenses of operating the school at Henvey Inlet will be met by the Vote for Indian Education.

I will be pleased if you will have passed in the Council a resolution, requesting the Department of Indian Affairs to re-open the school on the first of September, and giving us the assurance that the Council will give every assistance with a view to its successful operation.

Your obedient servant,

Moses Missanbie, Chief,
Henvey Inlet Reserve,
Byng Inlet, Ont.

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Enclosed you will find an application for position of teacher of Henvey Inlet. I should state that Mr. Elias is a product of the Anosy School, according to what he told me. The Deputy Supt General.

There does not appear to be any previous correspondence on file showing that repairs are required at this school.

The school building is a log one 19 ft by 25 ft inside measurement and if now in the condition reported by the Indian Supt., and deteriorating to such an extent within the last year, it is questionable if the erection of a new building would not be more profitable than repairing this old log building, as a new frame one of about the same dimensions as this old one could be erected for very little more than required to put this building in shape.

The estimate sent in for repairs is not very definite and it is not clear if the plastering is included or if the paint estimated is to be put on the building or if it is intended to charge extra for the labor in this work.

A short specification should be sent showing clearly the extent of the work to be done so that an estimate of the cost may be made.

Ottawa, July 26, 1906.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 16th inst., inclosing a communication from the Chief of the Henvey Inlet band in regard to repairing the school-house on the reserve, the cost of which will be in the neighborhood of $450.

In reply I beg to say that the Department is doubtful whether it would be wise to incur so large an expenditure in repairing this existing old log school-house, when a new frame building of the same dimensions could be put up for about $700. The estimate which accompanied your letter is not very definite, and it is not clear if the plastering is included or if the paint estimated for is to be put on the building, or whether it is intended to charge extra for the labour in this work. A specification should be sent showing clearly the extent of the work to be done, so that an estimate of the cost might be made.

In any event the Department would not authorize expenditure of the amount asked for without a resolution of the band approving of the same, and as the matter would have to be submitted to the Indian council it would be better to bring up both questions, that is the erection of an entirely new building or repairing the old, and it will be for the Indians to decide, as the necessary funds will have to be taken from their capital.

W. B. Maclean, Esq.,
Indian Superintendent,
Parry Sound, Ont.

Your obedient Servant,

In reply to your letter of the above date which refers to the proposed repairing of the School House at the Henvey Inlet Reserve I beg to say that I visited this reserve on the 2nd instant and while there examined the School House and am of the opinion that it would be better to build an entirely new building in preference to spending the amount of money that would be required to repair and rebuild the present structure. The building is a very old one and the sills and walls appear to be in a very rotten condition.

The Band desire to have a new School house built, but before anything is decided I would suggest that you have a drawing made of a suitable building so that I can call for tenders and find out what the building will cost. The measurements of the building required will be as follows: length 26 ft., width 20 ft., and height 16 ft., with a stone or concrete foundation.

I might say in regard to the building of this school house that I think it will cost more than your estimate which is $700.00 as the Henvey Inlet Reserve is an inaccessible place. If the erection of this building could be delayed until the completion of the James Bay or Canadian Pacific Railways it would very much cheapen the cost of the building, as both of these roads run through the reserve, and the material would not require to be hauled more than 2 miles, whereas, at present, it can only be taken to the reserve by Sail Boats. Awaiting your further instructions in the matter I beg to remain.

Your obedient Servant,

Indian Supt.

The estimate submitted for repairs to the Henvey Inlet School is very much below the probable cost of doing the work and no estimate is made for painting or repairs to plastering in either building.

I beg to report that I have inspected the Henry Inlet Indian School, which is completed according to specification. I may say that I inspected the material used during the construction. The lumber, lath, lime, and shingles were of first quality. The workmanship was done in every part. I may say that I had Mr. White put a ventilator in the school room ceiling to carry off surplus heat and accumulation of foul air. (This was omitted in the plan and specifications.)

The steps at the entrance of the school room are made of concrete, neat and substantial.

The school is painted a dark gray or slate color two coats, lime well down. The chimney is built of concrete brick according to plan. The foundation is concrete and well done. The water closets are neat and commodious, and isolate about one hundred feet apart. The repair to the teachers house is well done, and makes it comfortable and habitable. Sir,

I beg to report that there should be an addition built to Harvey inlet teacher residence. The Indians will do the work if the agent will supply the material. The present teacher at Harbordge is a good teacher and a married man. The house is only 15x17 and if it had an addition of say 12x16 it would make a much better house and would cost $300. The Harvey inlet school should have 16 double seats on each side. I would recommend the above improvements and seats to be purchased at once.

Chawunaga School should have a store to keep from getting under it so it is all open and must be very cold in winter. Also a teachers house should be built. The present one is in bad shape and not worth repairing.

4. New desks are required for these schools. The old ones are no good and school chairs, frames and windows need replaced. Mr. Taylor the late teacher has resigned. I think I could get Miss Beattie from Gillam because she has had some teaching experience. May I apply here and at what salary please let me know by return as possible. I am your obedient servant,

Sir:

Referring to that portion of your letter in which you deal with the question of erecting an addition to the teacher's dwelling at Henvey Inlet; and in reply, the Department is prepared to furnish the material for this addition to the dwelling 12 X 16, upon conditions that all the labour is performed by the Indians under your supervision. You should purchase all material at the closest possible price and be guided by the patronage list. The voucher for this material should be in full detail.

I inspected the school well and as it is on a hill side the surface water runs into it, (although it is a good spring).

Fixing well $5.00

Ottawa, May 7, 1915.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 23rd ultimo stating that when you last visited the Henvey Inlet school you found that certain repairs and improvements were needed, the estimated cost of which amounts to $105.00.

In reply I beg to say that you may have these repairs attended to and the cost should not exceed your estimate, with the exception of the fixing of the well, which will come to about $15.00 instead of $6.00 as given by you. The Department is of opinion that a cement curb about eight feet deep should be put in with a concrete cover and manhole to insure a clean supply of water and this work should be done for about $15.00, which would bring the total cost of the improvements up to about $115.00.

Your obedient servant,

I have received an offer of $50.00 from the Algonquin Timber Company for the old school building on the Henvey Inlet Reserve. I have recently inspected this building and find it in a very dilapidated condition as it has not been in use for a great number of years. Practically all the Indians of this Band had moved to their other Reserve on the Lower French a number of years ago. With the prospect of work by the new licensee on the Henvey Inlet Reserve, some families are already moving back there. However, the trend of settlement now appears to be along the line of the railway which would be about three miles distant from the old school with a body of water (Henvey Inlet) in between.

The school building would have some salvage value in lumber which the Algonquin Timber Company could use in the construction of the camps, it being somewhat difficult to transport the lumber to this point. I consider that $50.00 would be the full salvage value of this building, although its value to us as it stands would be considerably more should we ever find it convenient to refit it as a school which, however, I consider unlikely.

Should you decide to consider the offer made by the Algonquin Timber Company, please advise me as soon as possible.

Samuel Devlin,
Indian Agent.

Sir,

I beg to enclose you herewith a letter received from Chief Joe Aheahawasagai of the Henvey Inlet Band, the first part of which refers to the completion of the school teacher's house, lumber & material for which are now on the ground.

The understanding in regard to the building of the house was, that the men of the Band were to do the work required in completing the building, & they promised to do so when I visited the Reserve in August last. It is quite evident however from the chief's letter that they do not now intend to carry out this promise, & as it is most important that the work of completing the house should be done at once, before the cold weather sets in, I beg to recommend that the chief's request that the sum of $60 be paid to the three men to finish the house be granted.

I may add that the teacher Miss Ada McIntosh will undoubtedly resign her position unless the house is completed, & it will be a most difficult task to induce anyone to go there to take charge of the school, unless there is a house for the teacher to live in.

In regard to the chief's request that a scaler be sent up to scale the logs, now being taken out on their Reserve by Miss Burton & Son, on behalf of the Band, I beg to say that I do not consider
Sir,

it necessary to have a scale set up for this purpose, for the reason that the logs are being taken out by contract by Thomas Wilcox of Parry Sound, & the experience of lumbermen in this District who have taken out logs by contract has been that the contractor always gets a good scale for the logs he takes out. I therefore think that the scale now being made by an Ontario licensed scaler will be a correct one & cannot see the necessity of appointing another to scale on behalf of the Indians, unless there are good & sufficient reasons given why such action should be taken.

Your obedient servant,

W.M. Maclean

Sir,

I beg to inform you that the following improvements and repairs are required to be made to the teacher house at the Henry Inlet Reserve:

- Interior of house requires painting, both floors & walls.
- Brick chimney is required.

The cost of these improvements will be about as follows:

- 2 gallons paint for floor at $0.50 per gallon = $1.00
- Walls at $0.50 = $0.75
- 1 barrel Oil = $1.50
- 2 Brushes = $0.15
- 600 Bricks @ 10¢ each = $6.00
- 1 lb. Lime = $1.75
- Labor 1 day for 1 man at $1.50 = $1.50
- Freighting material from Byng Field = $3.00

Total Cost = $24.75

When I visited Henry Inlet in July last I noticed that there was no brick chimney at the teacher house, the stove pipe being merely run through the roof, which is
Indian Agent's Office,

263798

Most dangerous, so that a brick chimney is absolutely necessary for safety.

The interior of the house is not plastered; the walls being sheathed boards. Painting the walls & floor will make the house much more habitable & more easily kept clean & this is a consideration which will make it easier to secure a teacher for the school at this Reserve.

I have secured a teacher to re-occupy the Henry Inlet School on October 1st in the person of Miss Ada Mcintosh who has formerly been in charge of this School, & I desire to have the improvements completed before her arrival at the Reserve. I will therefore thank you to authorize me to have the work done as soon as possible.

I wish Chief Joe Akahawaragai on the 1st met about this matter & attach herewith his reply.

All of the materials required can be purchased at Kyng Inlet but will have to be freighted to the Reserve in a sail boat a distance of 15 miles.

Your obedient servant

I beg to submit accounts and report on the new addition to teacher residences at Henry inlet. I may say that building is all completed and makes a very much needed improvement in the teacher quarters.

The signal arrangements are that the Dept. was to supply the material and the Indians do the work. After materials were sent they refused to go on with the work. I wrote the Department for authority to engage a White man (contractor) to work up but found the lumber was still lying at the wharf and the building place not being very desirable he came back. So I went up and arranged with the Indians to go ahead with the work and engaged a few them about half what the White man wanted. I shall the teacher help there time and allowed them 15 cents per hour which was I think about a normal amount to generally get the job done but I think in future it would be better to let the work be given White men or Indians by contract—it would be more satisfactory as it takes too much looking after. In this case the teacher Joe Partridge is a very honest fellow and as he was anxious to get the job done took considerable interest in the work and charged out three or four times to make things come into all right.

Hon. Regd. Ess,

Sir,

I beg to report that Miss Hayes, teacher of
the Skene Indian School, Parry Island, has today tendered
her resignation with the request that it take effect forthwith
but at all events on the 31st Dec. next.

In view of the facts that Miss Hayes has become discontented
with her position—that friction apparently exists between her
and the parents of some of her pupils in consequence of which,
apparently, the school attendance is reduced to the smallest
possible number I beg to recommend that her resignation
be at once accepted and that a new teacher be engaged
or that the school be closed till the 1st January next.

I recognize that by the 5th regulation relating to Indian
schools a Truant Officer may be appointed to enforce at-
tendance at school. In this case I would suggest that
before such an appointment is made, this section of the
Reserve should be deprived of its school for a short time—in
the hope that better attendance would result on the school
being removed. Jealousy of the other end of the Reserve, where
the Ryerson School would remain open, would probably prove
a factor in inducing the parents to send their children to school
in their own vicinity.

I am—Sir,
Your obedient servant,

J. Walton—Indian Sup't

Sir,

Referring to your letter, addressed to me,
dated 2nd July last, File No. 153, 879-18 instructing me,
me in consultation with Mr. School Inspector Grant, to
obtain the services of a properly qualified teacher for the
Stone Indian School after the Summer holidays. I beg to
report that we both failed to secure a teacher till about
the latter end of August when Miss Maggie, the former
teacher, applied to be again appointed to the School.

Some correspondence took place in the course of which
I stated "you may resume your School at once but
your salary for the September quarter will be according
to the proportion of days you actually teach in the quarter."

She commenced her work on the 14th September and
taught 13 days. Her salary is $200 per annum.

A difference of opinion exists between Mr. Grant and
myself as to the amount of remuneration to which this
teacher is entitled.

I consider that she should receive $\frac{13}{216}$ of $200
thus being 216 teaching days in the year or the sum of $12.44
Mr. Grant considers that we should find the average number
of teaching days in the September quarter and pay her
according to the proportion of days she has taught to that
number.
My objections to his contention are that it is rather difficult to find the number of teaching days in a September quarter—that she was not engaged till the 14th September when she assumed charge of the School and has not consequently any right to receive advantage of the Summer holidays for that she would thereby receive $25 for 13 days' work which seems unreasonable.

His objections to my contention are that Miss Maguire having taught during the first and second quarters of the present year and part of the third quarter namely, 135 days is entitled 5/6 of the annual salary, that is $125—that she has received $100 and is therefore justly entitled to $25. He puts it in another way as follows—That teachers in the employ of the Department receive the full salary of the September quarter for teaching from 26 to 30 days and that she having taught 13 days is justly entitled to half the quarter's salary namely $25.

Mr. Grant ignores the fact that the teacher completely severed her connection with her School on the 30th June and entered into a totally new engagement on the 14th Sept.

While I do not admit that the adjustment of an Indian School teacher's salary comes within the province of a School Inspector's duty, I think it proper, lest any injustice be done either to the teacher or the Parry Island Interest fund, to lay the matter before you for decision.

I have, of course, sent in the teacher's salary requisition according to my view of the case.

I also send in a requisition for school materials.

I have the honour to be

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Mrs. Walton
Indian Agent

Woodville, Dec 20th, 1911.

Mr. D. F. Macdonald,
Parry Sound, Ont.

Dear Sir,

Hearing that the Shene Indian school is vacant I beg to offer you my services as teacher.

I have not a Provincial certificate. I tried the District exam at Lindsay in 1906.

My teaching experience extends over three years. I taught for one year at Madawaska, one year at Goderich, Lake of Bays, Muskoka, and I have taught the Gibson Indian Reserve school in Muskoka, as you know. I left the same to take stenography which does not agree with my health. I am of Scotch parentage and of Presbyterian persuasion.

I will endeavor to do my best by the Indian children, regardless of their religious persuasion! Their advancement and welfare will be my aim.

Remain, Yours sincerely,

Maude Forsell.
Parry Sound

Dear Sir,

I would respectfully appeal, and under any present difficulties before you trusting you will plead my cause before the Dept. of Indian Affairs, that on my taking charge of Skinner School at Perry Island, for a salary of $57.50 per annum.

Permit me to say that I have no idea for the unpleasantness and inconvenience surroundings so far away from all the civilization of the world. I have to buy for all the necessaries, and wood beside, and the living is so high.

In conclusion I find that the fixed salary are not sufficient to keep for one going. I feel I ought to be earning more $40.00 at least. Perhaps when you take into consideration the fact that I have been devoted my time to what few scholars there is in this lonely spot, I assure you no qualified teacher would devote their
Their time, more than I do and you will not think this is unreasonable request, and be inclined to grant. I need not say that in any case while I remain in this place my best energies will continue to be as they have hitherto been, devoted to their entire interests.

Trusting to be favored with a kind consideration regarding this matter,

I have the honor to be Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Mary D. McCaig

On my recent visit to the school at Farry Island (received Aug 30th) I found the water closet at the school in a complete wreck having been blown down in a storm. It was previously in a very dilapidated condition. A new one should therefore be erected at once.

I discussed the question of the cost of building the new one with the Chief and one of the councillors in this office today. Councillor Thomas Lathem agrees to build a new one, size 8 ft x 4 ft being a double closet for the sum of $70.00. This sum to include cost of all materials.

Skene School

Indian school, Parry Island.

This school is about nine miles from the Ryerson School. Mr. Kelvie is in charge of the school and holds a Third Class Provincial Certificate, and has been in charge for over five years. The few children who attend school through the teacher's persuasion, are making some progress in their studies.

The school house is built on a slight sandy slope in front of a large lumber harbor, with spacious play grounds. The structure is built on cedar posts, which makes it very cold in the winter. The cold draft coming through floor necessitates a continuous heavy fire in the stove. If a concrete or stone foundation was built under the building room, the expenditure would be saved from the extra fuel that is consumed in keeping the school room warm.

The wood shed built last fall, has proven a boon in keeping the wood dry and fit for fuel.

The water closets are dilapidated. The two compartments are joined in fact there is no privacy or seclusion in the present closets.

The school should be repaired with a new floor and paint and other minor repairs. Then the Skene School would be a substantial and comfortable building for years to come.

The fence around the teachers house requires some repairs. Also, if a small wood shed was built for the teachers use, with a door and lock thereon, would prevent the pilfering of wood.

D. Macdonald

Sir:

Sir,

To the Chief,

Sincerely Encouraged,

My dear Sir — I am sending this note out by Mr. Peter James to lay before the worthy Chief & Council. It reached here late on Sat last & have waited so often since that I could see you. I am sorry to say that I did not find matters so satisfactory as I could have desired. In the first place I never thought to find me bedding furnished. I did not think that the teacher would be supposed to bring bedding or any household utensils with her. I might have asked Mr. McLean about that sort of thing but never thought such would be in the cottage.

Now Chief, I should like to ask your opinion about the matter. I thought perhaps you might deem it advisable to furnish bedding & all other necessaries to work with, and have them
left in the cottage so that they might be available for all your teachers, as it is quite a little expense for the teachers on such small salary.

I am confident if you do so you will find everything in first-class condition when I leave your school.

Kindly allow me to submit a list of such articles as are really necessary— I. For bedding—
Think 2 pairs of flannel sheets, a good pair of heavy blankets, 4 or 2 comforters, 2 pillows with covers—I could make the covers and sheets if you preferred—this seems to me to be the very least that should be put along with. Do you not think so?

Mr. James will tell you the conditions the cottages is in.

II. There the dishes here comprise 3 bowls. There is needed a few everyday cups, saucers, knives, forks, plates, sugar cups, milk jug, pepper caster, dishpan, tea pie, bake plate, dust pan, oil can, wash board, broom & lamps and towels. When the chairs. We have no one to wash the floor with.

The cottage needs a thorough cleaning & the stove & fires need blacking to make the
place at all presentable or to give any assurance
of our good faith to him in his former offer
to come into it. I have looked over the school
room and it is entirely clean.

Now Chief may be reassured by the hope that
my opinion about the matter may coincide
with yours.

All of which is respectfully submitted,

J.E. Armour

Sir,-

I have the honour to reply to your two letters, No.154420, of the 5th and 15th March inst.

Last fall on the receipt of the decision of the Department to put into force the compulsory clause in regard to the education of Indian children, I informed the members of the band at a meeting of the decision of the Department in this regard, and after consultation with them I selected Jean Tahamont as Truant Officer for the Protestant school of the village.

Sometime ago Jean Tahamont came and complained to me that there were several children who did not attend school regularly in spite of his warnings, and he asked me to write to the persons in charge of these children and to warn them that they were rendering themselves liable to trouble if they did not send their children regularly to school. Accordingly I did so.

Some days later Jean Tahamont came back and told me that the same state of affairs continued, and that he wished to take legal proceedings against these persons. I then told him to wait a little, as I would go myself and see these persons, in order to find out why they did not comply with our notification. Twice I went on this business. I saw the teacher, the Rev. H.O. Loiselle; I examined the
school register; I saw the persons complained of; I also saw other persons of worthy character, such as Chief Joseph Laurent and others; and the following is the information that I gathered.

The Truant Officer complained first of Louis Denis, who has living with him one of his grand-nephews, Louis Paquette. Louis Denis is a Roman Catholic; he is married to a Protestant. His grand-nephew, Louis Paquette, is the child of his brother-in-law, Thomas Paquette, who is nominally a Protestant, but who in fact does not profess any religion; I have myself for a long time known Thomas Paquette, who is a widower and who has several children; he is a drunkard and drinks all that he earns when he works, and he does not take any trouble about his children, who are scattered amongst people here and there. Louis, the one in question, has been living with his uncle Louis Denis for three years. Louis Denis tells me that his brother-in-law, Thomas Paquette, promised to pay him for board and maintenance for his child, but that he has never done so. Thomas Paquette has now been gone for some time; I cannot say where he is.

Louis Denis told me that he sent his nephew, Louis Paquette, who is about fifteen years of age, to school every day for two hours in the morning and for as much in the afternoon, and that during the rest of the time he kept him with him to assist him in his work of basket-making to do a little towards meeting the expense involved in his board and maintenance, and that he had not the means to keep him altogether for nothing. He told me, moreover, that he had spoken about him to the Rev. H.O. Loiselle, the teacher, and that the latter had replied that he was not complaining of this state of affairs. I saw the Rev. Loiselle; he told me that what Louis Denis had said was the truth and that it was not he who was complaining.
I then saw the Truant Officer, Jean Tahamont, and I told him that it did not seem reasonable to me to take legal proceedings against Louis Denis, and that it was difficult to exact from the latter that he should do more than he was doing; but Tahamont was not of this opinion and he continued to bother Denis and to threaten him.

After some days I went back to see them again and Denis told me then that since he could not have peace and quietness with a Protestant school he had decided to send his nephew to the Roman Catholic school. I told him that was his business; and for some time Louis Paquette has attended the Roman Catholic school.

Whoever made the complaint to the Department has not told the truth in saying that it was I who sent the child to the Roman Catholic school; Louis Denis did so of his own free will.

Moreover this is not the only Protestant who attends the Roman Catholic school, there are other Protestant families in the village who prefer sending their children either to the Roman Catholic school in the village or to the Convent of St. François du Lac. They are not solicited in this regard by the Roman Catholics, but the Rev. Sister who directs the school does not refuse to admit those who present themselves; nevertheless she abstains from speaking of religion to the Protestants, contenting herself with teaching subjects in which religion is not concerned.

As for my personal opinion, I think it would be an encroachment on the individual liberty of the parents to wish to compel them to send their children to one school rather than to another, and I do not believe that I have the power to do so. That is why, so long as children go to school, I do not think it my duty to interfere with them.

As for Louis Denis, I think he has been doing...
even more than his duty, and that in the position in which his nephew is he should have been able to keep him with him for two weeks each quarter in accordance with the provisions of the compulsory clause of the regulations in regard to the education of Indian children.

Some people tell me also that Jean Tahamont seems to wish to make use of his position to satisfy his personal dislikes.

If the Department desires to have fuller information on this subject, I shall give myself the pleasure of forwarding the same.

Hoping, however, that these explanations will be satisfactory to you, I beg to subscribe myself,

Your obedient servant,
A.O. Comire,
Agent.

N.B.
The Department did not tell me in its letter and of the 5th March inst., who it was who complained in regard to what child the charge was made, but if I have gone off in a wrong direction, please give me fuller explanations.

A.O.C.

Sir,

I have the honour to reply to your letter, No. 154520, of the 21st May inst.

On receipt of your letter of the 10th April last, No. 154520, in order to comply with your suggestions I called upon the Rev. H.O. Loiselle, the teacher of the Protestant school, and asked him to give me a list of the children who were not attending regularly, in order that I might see the parents of those children. He gave me the names of four children, namely, Solomon and Samuel Watso, children of Sam. Watso, Edwin Nagazona, son of J.B. Nagazona, and Maud Paquette, granddaughter of Robert Paquette, junior.

I told him that I was going to see the parents of those children, and that, if the attendance were not better, if he would inform me of the fact, I should see about taking more energetic measures; but I have not had any further news since, although on several days since that time I have passed through the village in order to take the census of the tribe.

I have seen the parents of the above mentioned children. Some of them told me that their children had been sick; another told me that he absolutely required his children to assist him in gathering drift-wood, which passes at this time in quantities down the river, and that
he was unable to let them go while he was collecting his fuel for the following winter. I told them all that they must send their children regularly to school without fail. They promised me to do so, and, as I stated above, I have not had any other news.

I do not see how the truant officer and the teacher can complain that I refused to assist them in obtaining regular attendance of the children at school. I refused permission to the truant officer to interfere with Louis Denis in connection with his nephew Louis Paquette referred to in previous correspondence, because I consider that in that case he had no right, and I am still of the same opinion.

There appears to be a conspiracy against me in order to discredit me with the Department. You will understand that the agent cannot always please everybody, God Himself does not succeed in that, and in some of the duties that I have to discharge sometimes it happens that there are some discontented people, for instance when I have to act in the capacity of Justice of the Peace and to condemn to prison some members of the band.

I believe in the education of children as much as any person, and I have given proof on many occasions by the sacrifices that I have made with that object; for eighteen years I was Secretary Treasurer of the School Commissioners of St. Pie de Deguire, a neighbouring parish, and I am at present and have been for three years President of the School Commissioners of the village of St. Francois du Lac. Of my six children two are at the Nicolet College, one of the best in the Province of Quebec, the third is in a first-class private school, and the three younger are boarders at the Convent of St. Francois du Lac. It seems to me that these are sufficient facts to testify as to my love for education.
The complaints brought against me are vague and have nothing precise in them; it is rather difficult to reply to them in a satisfactory manner.

Please tell me who is the guardian whom I advised to take his children from the Protestant school and send them to the Catholic school?

If I had precise and detailed charges, I could give you more complete information in regard to each case.

Please also tell me what is the section of the law that forbids parents sending their children to a school or institution of their choice for them to be educated there, in order that I may myself be able to explain to the parents in regard to these complaints, that would be more satisfactory to them, and would give greater effect to my instructions in this matter, for it may happen that these parents have not decided to change the school once more.

The law in regard to the Indians, and particularly the compulsory clause, is made for the whole Dominion, but it may be that the means that would suit the Indians of the Northwest Territories or Manitoba would not be suitable for the Abenakis of St. Francis, who are as much civilized as white men and who have for the most part half or three-quarters of white blood in their veins.

In my humble opinion I believe that it would be better to try gentleness and persuasions again before resorting to rigorous measures.

Again, it is possible that the Rev. Mr. Loiselle may not possess in a sufficient degree the aptitude and ability necessary to make a good teacher in order to draw the children to the school and to make them like the school. It seems to me that it would have been much wiser

J'ai l'honneur d'accuser réception de votre lettre No 154520 en date du 28 octobre dernier, et en réponse je dois vous dire qu'en effet l'assistance à l'école protestante du village des Abénaquis n'est pas satisfaisante, surtout depuis les derniers mois de l'année dernière et le commencement de cette année.

Ce serait trop long d'expliquer au Département tous les détails de cette affaire là qu'il me suffise de dire que la principale cause réside dans un différend qui existe entre l'instituteur, le Rév. Leiselle et la famille de Samuel Watse depuis plusieurs années déjà et qui va toujours en s'aggravant de plus en plus, à tel point que vers la fin de l'année dernière il y eut entre eux une petite bataille, et ils se sont poursuivis mutuellement devant les tribunaux et le procès doit se plaider dans le mois prochain.

L'instituteur dit que les enfants de Watse sont paresseux, qu'ils ne savent jamais leurs leçons, et il les punit, d'un autre côté, Watse prétend que l'instituteur est trop sévère, trop strict, et qu'il punit ses enfants injustement et comme conséquence il ne veut plus envoyer ses enfants à l'école et quelques uns des parents de Watse, par sympathie sans doute, ont suivi son exemple.

Il est assez difficile, au travers de tout cela, de savoir
qui a tort et qui a raison; il est possible qu'il y ait
du peur et du centre des deux côtés.

Depuis l'hiver dernier, je suis allé moi-même plusieurs
fois, voir l'instituteur et Watse chacun leur
teur, afin de tâcher de rétablir l'accord entre eux; j'em-
ployai tous les moyens de persuasion à ma disposition et
sur mes instances, Watse consentit une fois, le printemps
passé à renvoyer ses enfants à l'école mais cela
ne dura pas longtemps.

Monsieur Samuel Bray, lors de sa visite à la réserve,
l'été dernier, sur ma recommandation, alla aussi les voir
dans le même but.

Monsieur H.L. Masta le surveillant (truant officier) me
me dit avoir fait les mêmes démarches plusieurs fois,
sans plus de résultat, de sorte que dernièrement il me
dit qu'il préférait me donner sa démission de surveil-
lant (truant officier) plutôt que de prendre des précé-
dés de rigueur, qui disait-il n'auraient pas de meilleurs
résultats; c'est aussi mon opinion.

Watse est très entêté et il ira en prison et payera l'a-
mende plutôt que de renvoyer ses enfants à l'école, tant
que le Rev. Leiselle sera là et je ne conseillerais pas,
du moins pour le présent de recourir à ces moyens là; je
pense que cela ne ferait qu'empirer les choses.

Je les ai revu encore une fois tous les deux la semaine
passée, mais je n'ai pas mieux réussi; comme j'insistais
autres de Watse, sur la nécessité qu'il y avait peur lui,
dans l'intérêt de ses enfants, de les envoyer à l'école, et
et de ne pas les laisser grandir dans l'ignorance, quand
même il n'aimerait pas l'instituteur, il me répondit qu'il
avait besoin de ses enfants pour lui aider à arracher ses
patates et qu'ensuite il les enverraient dans une autre
école, mais je pense qu'il ne l'a pas encore fait.

Dans le moment, je ne vois pas de remèdes à la situation
Peut-être que ce sera plus facile lorsque leur procès sera fini.

Mais à présent, aucun d'eux ne veut abandonner ce qu'il prétend être ses justes réclamations contre l'autre.

Vous pourrez avoir de plus amples détails sur cette affaire là de Mr. Samuel Bray qui a entendu le pour et le contre l'été dernier.

Sir,

I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of your letter, No. 154520, of the 20th inst., and in reply I beg to say, in fact, the attendance at the Protestant school in the Abenakis village has not been satisfactory, especially since the latter part of last year and the beginning of this year.

It would take too long to explain to the Dept. all the details of this matter; it is sufficient for me to say that the principal cause of the trouble is the difference which exists between the teacher, Rev. Mr. Loiselle, and the family of Samuel Watso for several years, and which is getting worse all the time, to such an extent that about the end of last year they had a fight, and they have entered actions against each other and the trial will take place next month.

The teacher says that Watso's children are idle, that they never know their lessons, and he punishes them; on the other hand, Watso maintains that the teacher is too severe, too strict, and that he punishes his children unjustly, and he will not send his children any more to the school; and some of Watso's relatives, through sympathy no doubt, have followed his example.

It is rather difficult, in the face of all this, to know who is right and who is wrong; it is possible
that they are both partly right.

Since last winter I have gone myself several times to see the teacher and Watsc in turn, in order to try to establish peace between them; I employed all my powers of persuasion, and at my instance Watsc consented once, last spring, to again send his children to the school, but that did not last long.

Mr. Samuel Bray, at the time of his visit to the reserve last summer, also went to see them with the same object.

Mr. H.J. Masta, the truant officer, tells me that he has also made an attempt several times with no better result, so that lately he says that he would sooner give hand in his resignation as truant officer than take severe measures, which, he says, would have no better result; this is my own opinion.

I again saw both of them last week, but I had no better success; when I insisted with Watsc on the necessity, in the interests of his children, of his sending them to school and not allowing them to grow up in ignorance because he himself did not like the teacher, he replied that he had need of his children to aid him to take up his potatoes and that afterwards he would send them to another school, but I think that he has not yet done so.

At present I do not see any remedy to the situation; perhaps this will be more easily seen when the trial is over.

But at the present time neither of them wishes to give up what he contends to be his just claims against the other. You will be able to get full details of the matter from Mr. Samuel Bray, who heard both sides last summer.

Your obedient Servant,

A.O. Comiré,
Agent.
Sir,

He incurs the hatred of the Indians that he has drawn on himself by his dishonesty, his insolence, his sarcastic humour, his insulting and bitter language — the deep-rooted hatred of the Indians that he has incurred by his low and obvious villainy — this implacable hatred demands not only that this wicked hypocritical schoolmaster be discharged, but also that he cease
the place, or this mortal hatred will cry for vengeance. His great villainy will be unmasked.
