WILLIAM PAQUETTE.—Il dira ce qu'il sait lors de l'enquête, si elle a lieu.

SAMUEL MSADOQUIS.—Est actuellement absent de la réserve; il est employé comme guide, dans le nord, pour des chasseurs; sa femme qui est catholique et dont tous les enfants sont catholiques ne connaît rien de cette affaire là.

LOUIS TAHAMANT.—Lui-même n'a pas d'enfants et il n'a aucune plainte personnelle à faire contre le Rév. Loiselle, cependant il a entendu dire par les enfants qu'il dormait durant l'école.

ROBERT PAQUETTE.—N'a aucune plainte à faire contre le Rév. Loiselle.

JOHNSON TAHAMANT.—Il demeure avec son père; sa femme est aux États-Unis, avec ses enfants depuis longtemps; il a entendu dire par les enfants que le Rév. Loiselle dormait durant l'école; il n'a pas d'autres plaintes à faire.

SAM. WATSON.—N'a pas voulu rien me dire; il réserve cela pour l'enquête, si elle a lieu.
J.B.Watso.-C'est le fils de Sam.Watso; il est garçon et demeure avec son père; je n'ai pu le voir, parce qu'il est actuellement absent de la réserve, employé comme guide, pour des chasseurs, dans le nord du St.Maurice.

LOUIS WATSO.-Il est parti pour les États-Unis et je n'ai pas pu le voir; c'est le fils de Sam.Watso et le grand-père de Jean Tahamant, deux des signataires de la plainte.

Avant de partir, il envoyait ses enfants à l'école catholique, parce que, disait-il, ses enfants n'apprenaient rien à l'école protestante; ce n'est que peu de temps avant de partir qu'il a envoyé ses enfants à l'école catholique. C'est lui qui a écrit la plainte, si je puis en juger par son écriture et c'est lui qui a passé parmi les protestants pour les faire signer, cependant ce ne doit être lui qui l'a rédigé, si je puis en juger par le style, il ne sait pas assez le français pour cela.

J'ai vu aussi quelques uns des autres membres de la bande qui ont des enfants qui vont à l'école du Rév. Loiselle et voici un résumé de leurs réponses:

GEORGE PAQUETTE.- Il a trois enfants qui vont à l'école du Rév. Loiselle et il en est bien satisfait, il dit que ses enfants ont fait beaucoup de progrès; il dit aussi que le Rév. Loiselle tient le temps correct à son école; ses enfants n'ont jamais rapporté que le maître dormait durant l'école.

VICTORIA ANNANCE épouse de Daniel Emmett Sr., dit:

Elle a un petit garçon qui va à l'école ainsi qu'un autre petit garçon qu'elle a actuellement en soin et elle bien satisfaite de la manière dont le Rév. Loiselle fait son devoir; elle dit que ses enfants font beaucoup de progrès; l'école commence toujours à l'heure réglementaire.
et finit de même.

SOLOMON BENEDICT.— est un protestant marié à une catholique et dont les enfants sont catholiques; cependant il demeure tout près de l'école et il dit que l'école commence et finit toujours à l'heure réglementaire; il n'a pas voulu signer la plainte lorsque Louis Watson a été le trouver dans ce but.

Maintenant je vais prendre chacun des griefs de la plainte en particulier et vous dire ce que j'ai pu apprendre à ce sujet.

Il y a certainement quelques uns des membres protestants de la bande qui n'aiment pas le rév. Loiselle et surtout Sam Watson, qui se plaint depuis longtemps que le rév. Loiselle maltraite ses enfants et qui a eu avec lui un procès qu'il a perdu toujours à propos de l'école et de ses enfants. Le rév. Loiselle dit que ces accusations là ne sont pas vraies et qu'il a traité les enfants de Watson comme les autres; et il m'a été impossible de découvrir lequel des deux qui dit la vérité.

En outre de cela, le rév. Loiselle me dit que H.L. Watson a l'ambition de le supplanter comme instituteur et que c'est lui qui travaille en dessous pour lui causer tous les embarras et que de doit être lui qui est l'auteur de la plainte bien qu'il ait été assez prudent de ne pas la signer. H.L. Watson, malgré que sa conduite ne soit pas exemplaire, jouit, à cause de son instruction, d'une certaine influence parmi les membres protestants de la bande, et le rév. Loiselle dit qu'il se sert de cette influence ou à pour lui causer des embarras.

L'organiste, dont il est question dans la plainte, est justement une des filles de Sam Watson; quand même le rév. Lois...
Loiselie l'aurait fréquentée, je ne vois pas un grand mal à cela; seulement il y a une contradiction, la plainte accuse le Rév. Loiselie de ne pas avoir voulu la marier, et lorsque j'ai questionné la femme de son frère à ce sujet, elle m'a dit que c'était la fille qui n'avait pas voulu du Rév. Loiselie.

La plainte dit aussi que le Rév. Loiselie aurait des jeunes filles à venir coucher chez lui. À ce propos voici les explications que m'a donné le Rév. Loiselie et qui sont corroborées par le témoignage de Hermine Paquette, épouse de Clitus Gauthier, Marie-Jeanne Paquette épouse de J.B. Nagazon et Marie Nagazon fille du précédent.

La petite Marie Nagazon demeurait chez le Rév. Loiselie, une Dello Anna Blouin, pensionnait là aussi; un certain soir, elles eurent la visite de la fille de Hermine Paquette et comme il pleuvait à torrents après la veillée, la petite Marie Nagazon, invita sa cousine à rester à coucher, ce que cette dernière accepta et elles couchèrent toutes les trois dans le même lit et la petite Marie me dit qu'elles n'eurent pas connaissance que le Rév. Loiselie soit venu les trouver.

Cette fille d'Hermine Paquette (Pamela Gauthier) est celle dont la plainte dit qu'elle ne maria plus tard à un étranger, un américain d'origine allemande, du nom de Rainey Schmink; elle eut souvent des querelles avec son mari, qui était dit-elle ivrogne ou jaloux; ils s'entraînaient tous deux chez Clitus Gauthier époux de Hermine Paquette et père de la jeune femme (Pamela Gauthier).

Un jour que Schmink avait fêté toute la journée et n'était pas revenu à la maison depuis le matin, sa femme partit vers 4 heures de l'après-midi, pour aller se promener.
promener chez sa tante, Marguerite Dupuis, épouse de J.B. Nagasoe; le soir lorsque Schminke revint à la maison, il demanda où était sa femme et apprenant qu'elle était, il partit avec sa balle d'or pour aller la chercher; en arrivant chez Nagasoe, Schminke commença à faire du tapage et à vouloir battre sa femme; alors cette dernière en compagnie de sa mère, se réfugia chez le Rèv. Loiselie, où il y avait Marie Nagasoe et Anne Blouin; Schminke ayant appris que sa femme était rendu chez le Rèv. Loiselie, il y rendit, les portes étaient fermées mais elles n'avaient pas barres; c'était vers 6 heures du soir et tout était l'automne; en arrivant là Schminke entra d'abord dans le passage sans frapper, puis il frappa à la porte de la salle et entra; en apercevant son mari la jeune femme se sauva dans la cuisine ou il la suivit, il parlait fort et avec animation ce qui attira les curieux des environs, et comme les portes étaient restées ouvertes quelques une entrèrent, entr' autres Louis Watson qui essaya de calmer Schminke; enfin ils partirent tous ensemble, au bout d'environ dix à quinze minutes.

La plainte accuse aussi le Rèv. Loiselie d'avoir courtisé une femme mariée, malgré nos informations, je n'ai pu rien y apprendre à ce sujet.

Quant à l'histoire des certificats, le Rèv. Loiselie dit la chose complètement et je n'ai pu rien apprendre à ce sujet.

Pâtes sur gages, usure, etc.; le Rèv. Loiselie a chez lui un orgue qui appartient à la famille de Louis Demers; plus tard cette famille souhaitait porter pour les élections et n'avait pas d'argent; après beaucoup d'insistance, le Rèv. Loiselie consentit à leur avancer $50.00, qui devaient être remboursées dans l'automne et qui le furent en
effet durant le cours de l'été, seulement l'orgue est encore là tout simplement parce que la famille n'est pas encore venue le reclamer.

Montée: Alfred Maodoquis avait déposé en gage une montre chez un monsieur Shomer de Pierville pour la somme de $6.80; comme Maodoquis était aux États-Unis et qu'il ne pouvait retirer sa montre, il écrivit à quelqu'un de ces amis de la retirer et de la garder, ce que ce dernier fit; plus tard le Rév. Loisel le lui acheta de lui et depuis il l'a revendu à un autre. C'est là tout ce que j'ai pu apprendre à propos des prêts sur gages.

À ma connaissance le Rév. Loisel a eu un procès avec Sam. Watson l'hiver dernier; le Rév. Loisel avait gardé les enfants de Watson après la classe pour leur faire apprendre leurs leçons; Watson se rendit à l'école pour avoir ses enfants et sur le refus de l'instituteur, il s'en suivit une querelle, d'où est résulté le procès que le Rév. Loisel a gagné, du reste.

Insulte au prêtre catholique romain: Le Rév. de Gomagne était à faire la visite des familles de la réserve en même temps il entrait chez Sam. Watson, une famille protestante, il y rencontrera le Rév. Loisel, qui lui aurait dit-on parlé d'une manière un peu inconvenante.

Quant au temps d'école perdu par le Rév. Loisel, le Département n'a qu'à consulter les rapports de ce dernier pour se renseigner exactement.

C'est là tout ce que je peux apprendre au Département à ce sujet.

Votre obéissant serviteur,

H.O. Ouiie
St. Francois du Lac, May 26, 1905.

The Secretary,
Dept. of I.A.,
Ottawa.

Sir,

In reply to your letter, No. 154520, of May 11, the following is the information that I have been able to gather on this subject:

I would remark in the commencement that of all those who signed the complaint, there is only one who has children going to Mr. Loiselle's school; that is Jean Tahamant, who is raising one of the illegitimate children of one of his daughters. Of the other signers in the list, Sam. Watso has some children, but he has sent them to the R.C. school since the suit that he had with the Rev. H. Loiselle last winter and which he lost; there is also Louis Watso, son of Sam., who has some children and who, before setting out for the United States, sent them to the R.C. school, probably because his father had done so. None of the other signers have children able to go to school. Sam. Watso has been living in concubinage for many years with the wife of Frank Ododson, and it is some of the children that he has had by this woman whom he is sending to school.

Samuel Meadoquis is a Protestant who is married to a Catholic; all his children are Catholics and go to the R.C. school.

Robert Paquette is an old man, 84 years of age,
who lives with Sam. Watsc; he is the father of Watsc's concubine and he probably signed without knowing what he was signing; in any event I do not believe that he signed, for I do not think he can write.

J.B. Watsc is the son of Sam. Watsc; he is a young man, who lives with his father.

Lewis Tahamant has no children.

Alfred Msadoquis has only two or three children, the eldest of whom is not more than four years of age.

William Paquette, himself, has no children; he is married to the widow of the late Cesar Hannis, who has some children, but she has been in the U.S. for a long time with one of her daughters; one of her sons is beadle of the R.C. church and another son is in the reformatory in Montreal; besides, with the exception of William, who is a Protestant and lives alone on the reserve, all the members of his family are Roman Catholics.

Johnson Tahamant is married but he is alone on the reserve; his wife has been in the U.S. with her children for a long time.

I give these details to the Dept. in order that it may judge for itself the moral standing of those who signed this complaint and the interest they might have in the good government of the school. I have taken the trouble to go to see each of the signers individually and ask them what are the grievances that they have against Rev. Mr. Loiselle; the following is a synopsis of the replies I received.

Jean Tahamant. He complains that the Rev. Mr. Loiselle does not keep the regular school hours and that he often closes before the maximum hour set by the regulations; he has heard the children say that Mr. Loiselle sleeps during school hours; as for himself he does not like the master of the school and will not send
his children there.

Alfred Msadougis.—For himself he has no complaint to make against the Rev. Mr. Loiselle; he has no children of school age; he says that when Louis Watso came to him to have him sign this complaint he did not read it but that Watso explained to him that it was a letter to the bishop with reference to a meeting concerning the appointment of churchwardens.

William Paquette.—He will tell what he knows when there is an enquiry, if such should be held.

Samuel Msadougis.—He is at present absent from the reserve; he is employed in the North as a guide to the hunters; his wife, who is a Roman Catholic and all of whose children are Roman Catholics, knows nothing of the affair.

Louis Tahamant.—He, himself, has no children and he has no personal complaint to make against the Rev. Mr. Loiselle; however he has heard the children say that he slept during school hours.

Robert Paquette.—He has no complaint to make against the Rev. Mr. Loiselle.

Johnson Tahamant.—He lives with his father; his wife has been in the United States with her children for a long time; he has heard the children say that the Rev. Mr. Loiselle slept during school hours; he has no other complaint to make.

Sam. Watso.—He did not wish to say anything; he would reserve that for an enquiry if one should be held.

J.B. Watso.—He is the son of Sam. Watso. He is a young man and lives with his father. I could not see him because he is away from the reserve at present, employed as a guide to the hunters north of the St. Maurice.
Louis Watson.— He has gone to the U.S. and I was not able to see him; he is the son of Sam. Watson and the son-in-law of Jean Tahamant, two of the signers of this complaint. Before going away he sent his children to the R.C. school, because, he said, they were learning nothing at the Protestant school; it was only a short time before going away that he sent his children to the R.C. school. It was he who wrote the complaint, and who passed it among the Protestants for them to sign; however, it cannot have been he who composed it, if I can judge from the style: he does not know French well enough for that.

I saw, also, some of the other members of the band who have children going to school to Mr. Loiselle, and the following is a synopsis of their replies:

George Paquette.— He has three children who go to Mr. Loiselle's school and he is well satisfied; he says that his children have made good progress. He says, also, that Mr. Loiselle keeps the correct hours in his school; his children have never reported that the teacher slept during school hours.

Victoria Annance.— She says that she has a small boy who goes to the school as well as another small boy at present in her care and she is well satisfied with the way in which Mr. Loiselle performs his duties; she says that her children are making great progress. The school commences at the regulation hour and ends the same.

Solomon Benedict.— He is a Protestant married to a Roman Catholic, whose children are Roman Catholics; he lives very near the school and says that he begins at the regulation hour and ends every day at the same hour; he was not willing to sign the complaint when Louis Watson came to him with this object.
Now I am going to take each of the grievances in the complaint individually and tell you what I know in the matter.

There are certain Protestant members of the band who do not like the Rev. Mr. Loiselle, always with reference to the school and their children, especially Sam. Watso, who has been complaining for a long time that the Rev. Mr. Loiselle maltreats his children. The Rev. Mr. Loiselle says that these accusations are not true and that he treats Watso's children as he treats the others; and it has been impossible for me to find out which is telling the truth.

Besides that, the Rev. Mr. Loiselle tells me that H.L. Masta desires to supplant him as teacher and it is he who is working underhand to cause him all the trouble, and that he must be the author of the complaint, although he was prudent enough not to sign it. H.L. Masta, notwithstanding that his conduct is not exemplary, has, on account of his education, a certain influence among the Protestant members of the band, and Mr. Loiselle says he uses this influence to cause him trouble.

The organist, referred to in this complaint, is in fact a daughter of Sam. Watso; even though the Rev. Mr. Loiselle does associate with her I do not see any great harm in that; only, there is a contradiction here, the complaint accuses the Rev. Mr. Loiselle of not wishing to marry her, and when I questioned Watso's wife with reference to this she told me that it was the girl who did not wish to marry Mr. Loiselle.

The complaint says also that Rev. Mr. Loiselle induced some young girls to come to sleep at his place; with reference to this the following are the explanations given me by Mr. Loiselle and corroborated by the evidence of Hermine Paquette, wife of Clitus Gauthier, Marie Jeanne Paquette, wife of J.B. Nagazoa, and Marie
Nagazoa, daughter of the former. Little Marie Nagazoa was living with Mr. Loiselle and Miss Anna Blouin was boarding there also; on a certain evening they had a visit from the daughter of Hermine Paquette and as it rained heavily in the evening Marie Nagazoa invited her cousin to remain over night, which, the latter accepted, and they all three slept in the same bed and little Marie tells me that she had no knowledge that the Rev. Mr. Loiselle came and found them.

This daughter of Hermine Paquette (Pamela Gauthier) is the person who, the complaint says, afterwards married a stranger, an American of German descent, named Ranny Schminke; she often had quarrels with her husband, who was, she says, a drunkard and jealous; they both resided at the home of Clitus Gauthier, the husband of Hermine Paquette, and father of the young woman, Pamela Gauthier.

One day when Schminke had been drinking all day and had not come back to the house since the morning, his wife went out about 4 P.M. to walk to her aunt's house, Marie Jeanne Paquette, wife of J.B. Nagazoa. In the evening when Schminke returned to the house he asked where his wife was and on learning where she was he went with his mother-in-law to look for her. On reaching the Nagazoa house Schminke began to make a row and wanted to beat his wife; then the latter in company with her mother escaped to the house of the Rev. Mr. Loiselle, where were Marie Nagazoa and Anna Blouin. Schminke having learned that his wife had gone to Mr. Loiselle's house went there. The doors were closed, but not locked; it was about eight o'clock in the evening and late in the fall. On arriving Schminke entered at once into the hall without knocking; then he knocked at the door of the hall and then entered. On perceiving
her husband the young woman escaped to the kitchen, where he followed her. He spoke loudly and excitedly, which attracted the curious people of the neighborhood; and as the doors had remained open some of them came amongst others Louis Watson, who tried to quiet Schminke; finally they went away all together after about ten or fifteen minutes.

The complaint also accuses the Rev. Mr. Loiselle of having made love to a married woman; in spite of my enquiries I have not been able to learn anything on this point.

As for the story about the certificates the Rev. Mr. Loiselle denies the thing completely, and I have not been able to learn anything from the others.

Loans on pawn, usury, etc.— The Rev. Mr. Loiselle has in his house an organ belonging to the family of Louis Deny. One spring this family wanted to go off to the U.S. but having no money, after much urging, the Rev. Mr. Loiselle agreed to advance them $50, which was to be returned to him in the fall and which was in fact returned to him during the course of the summer, and the organ is still there, simply because the family has not yet come to claim it.

A watch,— Alfred Msadoquis deposited a watch on pawn at the house of Mr. Shooner of Pierreville for the sum of $6.50. As Msadoquis was in the U.S. and as he was unable to withdraw his watch he wrote to one of his friends to withdraw it and to keep it, which the latter did. Later the Rev. Mr. Loiselle purchased it from him and afterwards he resold it to someone else. That is all that I have been able to learn in regard to loans on pawn.
To my knowledge the Rev. Mr. Loiselle had a suit against Sam Watso last winter. The Rev. Mr. Loiselle had kept Watso's children after school to make them learn their lessons; Watso went to the school to get his children and on the schoolmaster's refusing, a quarrel ensued, resulting in the suit, which Mr. Loiselle won.

Insult to the R.C. Priest.—The Rev. Mr. deGonzague was making a visit to families on the reserve, and when he entered the house of Sam Watso, a Protestant family, he met there the Rev. Mr. Loiselle, who, they say, spoke to him in an unsuitable manner.

As for the school time lost by Mr. Loiselle the Dept. has only to consult the report from the latter to inform itself exactly.

That is all that I am able to inform the Dept. in regard to this subject.

Your obedient Servant,

A.O. Comire,
Indian Agent.

The Deputy Superintendent General,

Chief Solomon Benedict has just called here in reference to the Protestant school at St. Francois, which has been closed since Sept. 30, last. In fact it was only open a few days since June 30, as Mr. Page, the missionary who taught the school, was unable to attend to it on account of his other duties.

Dean Evans, of Montreal, was asked to nominate a successor on October 8, last, but up to the present time no reply has been received from him and Chief Benedict says that the Indians are anxious to have the school reopened at once and recommends that Mr. Henry Masta, who is a member of the band and a well educated Indian be appointed teacher. Masta taught the school many years ago but his services were dispensed with on account of his habits and mode of life. I understand that since then a great reformation has taken place in Masta and the Chief assures me that he has not used intoxicants for twenty years, and although he is separated from his wife he is living morally.

The Indians have for some time past complained of
of the teacher's and missionary's work being combined, as the school suffers in consequence, and they wish to have a teacher who can devote his whole time to the work. Benedict says, and I have been informed by other Indians, that of the two they would rather have a regular teacher than a missionary, as they could always obtain the services of a clergyman by paying for them. It seems too bad that the education of the Protestant children should be neglected, owing to the inability of the Church of England to provide a suitable teacher. The Department Pays the teacher's salary and in the interests of the Indians I think it should appoint one without further delay, as the Church has had ample warning and opportunity. If Masta was given the appointment temporarily, he could reopen the school at once, and as none of the Protestant Indians, I am informed, would object to the appointment, it is for you to say whether he might be given a trial or not.

Sir,

We, your humble petitioners, parents of school children, and other Indians professing the Protestant faith do hereby respectfully present that our school teacher Mr. Masta has accomplished more in one year than any of his predecessors did in two years at school.

The children like him to the extent that they would sooner please him than their parents. They need now no coercion and no reminder to go to school, for they themselves even those under age want to be there, as soon as the bell rings. The attendance is regular and has increased in number over two or more years.

It is a well known fact that Mr. Masta has some magnetic power or influence over his friends and acquaintances, but especially over his pupils and own children. As a matter of fact, we all like and esteem him very much.

He is a man who has a great interest in the education of the children and who loves to impart knowledge to everyone and all of us generally. And he has such a way of doing this that we are always interested and pleased to listen to him. A man with his qualifications could easily obtain a salary of $700.00-$800.00 a year, in some of the Western Provinces, but he prefers to work amongst his own people, for less money.

But Masta's salary is far from being a just distribution for his services, for as we have said, he does twice as much work as any man we have had so far, and by right he ought to get a twofold compensation.

Periville, the Aboriginals
Indians do not now live the Indian mode of life. Formerly we lived in our own wigwam or log cabin. It was a kitchen but answered all other purposes as well. It was used as a sitting room, parlor and bed rooms. The furniture consisted in one rustic bedstead and table, and a couple of chairs or benches of some make.

Our dwellings, now, are so good, comfortable and convenient as those of our White brothers. The Lord Bishop Farthing, the Venerable Archdeacon Norton and other clergymen are well pleased and satisfied with the accommodation and entertainment they received at Mr. Masta's while visiting here.

Hereafter, everyone deported to this place by the Dept of Indian Affairs would likewise be welcome to Mr. Masta's hospitality. We dare say that while luxury is wanting, you there would find better accommodation than can be got at the hotels here.

And dear Mr. Mclean we wish to remind you furthermore that, the Dept has done nothing towards providing this suitable dwelling for our teacher Mr. Masta, nor for the furniture and heating of said dwelling, as in the case of other teachers, or this and other reserves. The Dept does not spend a cent either for our church, that is for the salary of our missionary while all the other missionaries to the Indians in Canada receive a certain stipend from the Government. In consideration of all these facts, we your humble petitioners hereby respectfully beg of you to increase our teacher's salary. We ask not as at first intimated that a twofold compensation be given him; but we do most sincerely ask that his present salary of £35 be raised to £50 at least, or that £15 extra be allowed him for his house, furniture and fuel. We earnestly beg leave to offer you, Mr. Mclean, our school children who cannot but say that their teacher deserves all
Dear Sir,

June 21st, 1911

To-day I visited the Protestant Indian School at St. Francis Reserve. By the kind permission of the teacher, Mr. Henry R. Masta, I examined the pupils' progress in Reading, Writing and Arithmetic. The result in each case was highly satisfactory, especially in Arithmetic, which included a seven test in Addition, Subtraction, Multiplication and Division of Vulgar fractions. The pupils, most of whom are very young, seem to be very intelligent, diligent and obedient. The school is very neat, and the general culture seems to be very good. The discipline seems to be excellent, and manifests itself in the respectful tone and orderly deportment of the whole school.

Mr. Masta seems to me to be an efficient teacher. Including the subjects mentioned on the scale of Proficiency, he can teach English and French, and is able to explain matters to his pupils in their mother tongue. It is equally evident from the high average attendance that his pupils like him, and that the parents are well satisfied with his work.

Having taught and inspected schools for a number of years before I entered the University, I think I can speak from experience and am confident that I know a well equipped school when I examine it.

Under these circumstances I have no hesitation in characterising the Protestant Indian School at St. Francis Reserve, as well equipped.

The principles of rational inquiry and systematic ethical instruction which must necessarily be combined in order that the advancement of education be achieved, are obvious in this school.

I consider the school as I observe it.

I had the day the pleasure of visiting the Protestant School at St. Francis Reserve, and heard the children read and write, and examined their work in writing, arithmetic, grammar, geography and history. The results were very satisfactory. The younger children showed a knowledge of figures in addition and multiplication, which surprised me. And for the older ones, here a fair knowledge of grammar, geography and Canadian history. They seem to have the dates of important events well in hand. The children are well conducted.

There is none of that restlessness and wantonness which one sees so much in country schools—which I have no doubt is due to the influence of the teacher, Mr. H.C. Watts. Mr. Watts is an Indian, and can converse fluently in the English and French languages. I consider this a great boon especially for the younger children to whom he can explain matters in their native tongue.

The good result of his work is shown in the fact that one of his pupils in 1910-11 is now working on his Matric.
for Dartmouth College. In the midst of childhood and youth—which is our essentially formative, definitive, and instructive period—there is no hour of it lost to something with eternity—it is a good thing to have a teacher who inspires his pupils to seek the best in life.

The school is clean, neat, and very comfortable. Mr. Watts has informed me that a new screen door, new screen windows, a new platform, and some repairs to the roof have been added this year. I am of the opinion that the salary accruing from this work ($150.00 per annum) is not by any means sufficient for a man who devotes all his time and energy to the task. Sir,

In accordance with your circulars in regard to schools, I went on Friday, Dec. 20, to the Protestant school, conducted by Mr. H.L. Masta. The pupils, boys and girls, to the number of fourteen, were all present. I spent an hour and a half with them. I got them to read; I questioned them on arithmetic, geography, and the history of Canada. Mr. Masta got them to recite some little pieces by heart, and made them go through some gymnastic exercises.

I may say that they all gave me satisfaction. I am told that the teachers who taught at this school had much difficulty in getting the children to attend, and also that the progress was almost nil; this is easily explained, and the following is the chief reason in my opinion: these young Abenakis up to the age of about ten years do not go away at all, but live with their mothers, Abenakis; the latter speak to them only in the Abenakis language, so that these children who attend the school knowing only Abenakis and the teacher speaking only English, he can only with difficulty make himself understood. In my opinion this is the chief reason for the lack of success on the part of the teachers who preceded Mr. Masta. I consider that Mr. Masta has a great advantage—that of speaking Abenakis to these young children, and that this fact makes them understand what they would not comprehend if they had a teacher speaking only English.

I am giving you perhaps more details that I ought; but it is in order to make you appreciate the advantage of the services of Mr. Masta, speaking French, English and Abenakis. I believe that these explanations

After an interesting and prolonged visit at the Indian school on the St. Francis River, which took place today, it gives me great pleasure to record my satisfaction at finding everything in such good order. The clean comfortable well equipped school rooms; the intelligence & discipline shown by the pupils; the many indications of general progress being made; these all combined in impressing most favourably the interested outsider.

As Anglican missionary here, having my own children in school; and, knowing what I write, it is only fair to say that Mr. Henry L. Marta is fitted to be congratulated upon his efforts being crowned with such success in educating the young on this reserve.

I would like to add further, that it is most fortunate for the community that the services of Mr. Marta are available for the position of teacher here. He is in the prime of life; held in the highest esteem by all; has great influence over both parents & scholars; converses fluently in French, English & Indian. He is thus able to fill a most difficult position with profit & skill. To me, it seems that $600.00 per annum is the very lowest salary such a man should be asked to accept.

Today I visited the Indian School, conducted by Mr. H.J. Masta, on the St. Francois Indian Reserve, and it affords me great pleasure to report on its present condition.

Having been trained myself for the teaching profession and having taught several years afterwards, both in the elementary and advanced school, one might be permitted to say that one has a good idea of a well conducted school and its average ability of children.

The school building here is neat, clean, appears to be quite commodious. The seats are such as make children comfortable, which fact contributes much little to the good order and progress in school.

There is a good supply of maps and there is also a globe for use in teaching geography. The library contains quite a few books, but there do not appear to be many of the same kind, making it difficult to have more than two or three pupils reading the one lesson, whereas a reading room may enable to greater part of the whole school occasionally, and will be an advantage to all classes, particularly the lower classes. The English Grammar books are rather advanced. The school needs a supply of simple books for the smaller classes. I noticed all their arithmetic was of an advanced standard and not very suitable for younger children.

I examined the classes in reading, writing, arithmetic, geography, history, and found them very good in each and all. I was particularly struck with their reading as each child read very distinctly. This is more surprising when one considers the difficulty of mastering the English language. This success is due, no doubt, to the ability of their
Teacher, Mrs. Masta, & explain matters them in their native tongue. Their writing was good, showed good progress. In Arithmetic they are quite up to the standard; the older class worked some problems without any learning difficulty, under four simple rules, the Compound rule, Multiplication & Division, Addition & Interest etc. They also have a fair knowledge of Geography & Canadian History.

In appearance the children were tidy, very neat. They seemed very much at ease in school, showing that they were happy & at home with the teacher. Seeing such progress made in the school, one may inclined to say that it could be only a dream. They are very fortunate in having such an influential man as Mr. H.L. Masta, training children who will be future citizens of this great Dominion. These children are being influenced in every way for good. Mr. Masta is doing a large part toward forming a character of those who will be future inhabitants of this valley & he is to be heartily congratulated for his devotion to his people. The noble work he is doing.

The salary for Mr. Masta felt for this work is very small for a man of his ability, the Can. Church, fluent in the English, French, Indian tongues therefore could occupy a responsible position anywhere.

I must protest to the statement made by my predecessor that six hundred dollars ($600) is too low toward salary such a man deserves, looked & accepted.

David Combs
Missionary in Charge

LES INSTITUTEURS ONT LE DROIT DE VIVRE

Voilà que le coût sans cesse croissant de la vie a déterminé la justice des augmentations de salaires dans presque tous les domaines de l'activité nationale, on sait que les personnes qui s'adonnent à l'enseignement ont fait exception à la règle et qu'elles ont été oubliées par l'autorité chargée de pourvoir à leur subsistance.

C'est pour parer à cet oubli, de plus en plus inquietant, que les membres du personnel enseignant des quatre districts scolaires de Montréal se sont réunis, sans être demandés à l'école Normale de Sainte-Croix, afin de dire que 25 instituteurs ont pris part à cette réunion pour faire valoir l'importance que chacun d'eux y attachait.

La question soumise à l'assemblée tenait toute deux jours et elle fut examinée par les autorités scolaires le 16 octobre dernier, par le conseil Roy, et conduisant à un examen des traitements de tous les professeurs, jeunes ou âgés, célibataires ou mariés, par suite de la charge extraordinaire de la vie. Il ne va pas de soi dire que la situation ne fut pas bien longue sur un projet de solution urgente. Un bon nombre d'instituteurs souffrent déjà de l'exiguïté de leurs revenus, et le mal va se généralisant de plus en plus.

La résolution de l'assemblée aux autorités scolaires est donc : 1o d'augmenter de $400 le maximum de chacun des divers traitements ; 2o d'accorder à chaque professeur une augmentation annuelle de $100 au lieu de $50, et de donner à chacun un minimum de $300 pour chaque classe de traitement et à chaque instituteur, avec effet rétroactif à partir du 1er septembre 1917.

On voit qu'il ne s'agit pas ici de protestations exorbitantes, car même un salaire additionnel de $200 ne représente que $3.84 par semaine. Depuis trois ans, le coût hebdomadaire de la vie s'est sûrement accru dans des proportions plus fortes que ce maigre surplus de $3.84.

Aujourd'hui, nous avons besoin d'ajouter que la demande des instituteurs de Montréal est non seulement justifiée mais nécessaire, eu égard au prix élevé des choses essentielles à la vie de garde, et, aux services précieux qu'ils rendent à notre population.

Nous nous vantons d'appartenir à un pays démocratique et de ressources immenses, où la richesse matérielle est une possibilité pour le plus pauvre et le plus méritant. La carte affirme que nous sommes tous égaux. L'ouvrier, du rôle peu enviable de simple manœuvre, peut, à certains moments, à l'aise de circonstances favorables, s'élever à celui de patron ou d'entrepreneur. Le jeune homme qui agit comme commis dans une maison de commerce ou de finance, a le droit d'espérer qu'il jouera, plus tard, le rôle de son patron. À ces deux classes de personnes nous permettons d'ajouter une troisième, qui peut être appelée à l'avenir une, au moins, à l'aisance. Seules, les personnes qui se livrent à l'enseignement semblent accepter d'avance une carrière de sacrifice et de renoncement, une situation tout au plus capable de la plus rare et de la plus inflexible loyauté.

En ces temps où le mot patriotisme est employé à tout moment, même pour faire triompher des personnages sujets à caution et des causes douteuses, ne serait-il pas temps de lui donner sa signification réelle, de maintenir le sentiment du vrai et fidèle service de notre patrie, les instituteurs démontrant qu'ils cultivent l'intelligence et le cœur de la masse, moyennant des salaires insuffisants, sinon ridicules ?

Qu'on le remarque bien, nos classes enseignantes ne sont pas seulement des sacrifices, depuis que la guerre est commencée. Elles ont de tout temps travaillé à vil prix pour procurer au peuple le bien le plus précieux qu'il puisse conserver : l'éducation qui est la base sur laquelle repose tout le reste. Ce n'est pas seulement un service, mais une mission, une préoccupation qui doit être assurée, non pas par le seul moyen dont une nation puisse se servir pour s'élever au point de vue politique et social et pour atteindre une position de force.

Pour toutes ces raisons, la requête doit il est loi que cette requête ne manquera pas d'être vue d'un bon œil par la Commission scolaire de Montréal. Cette dernière se compose, en effet, de personnes en état de prêter l'illustration à ce qu'elle veut, et surtout, bien au contraire, de membres choisis de la classe enseignante, qui ont une expérience de première main en matière de salaire et de mode de vie.

In the early part of April last, I wrote to the Dept., asking that alterations and improvements be made to the school house, in order that the teacher may have his living quarters in it. I represented that such a change would allow me to rent my house and thus create another small source of revenue, of which I am badly in need. Up to the 1st May I had received no answer and there was no other alternative but to lose the chance of letting my house or to move into the school building. I consulted the Indian Agent and while he did not authorize me to move into it, he said he saw no reason why the Dept. would not approve it and I fully shared his opinion, since the improvement would be for the teacher whom he may be. I employed the Department's contractors Mr. Chas. Ed. Desrochers to remove the school furniture upstairs and to make partitions on the first floor for a living room, kitchen and a bed-room which was absolutely necessary.

He had that much done when the Indian Agent visited me and the Dept. had written to say: "No funds for that purpose." I personally submitted the case to Mr. Scott last spring and left with him the contractors bill certified by the Agent, amounting to about $150. Dear Sir,

I have visited our school teacher, Mr. Mesta, and sending his annual report to your Department. I will also add mine at Mr. Mesta's request.

Mr. Mesta has regularly visited the school during the past year, and I have examined the scholars and found them well taught in English, French, and Indian. Mr. Mesta does not intend his children shall forget their native tongue. In all my visits I have found the school under good rule and discipline, and the school itself clean and everything in perfect order. Since the school was moved, the health of the children seems improved by the improved air, and in case of fire there would be plenty of room inside of the building. The children are regular in attendance, and a renewal of the old ones are taking a moral course, which will bring advantage to them if they take a higher course in education.

Your Department will see that our school is progressing, much to our Bishop's satisfaction, who takes a great interest in this school, which he considers his church school on the Reserve.

I am glad to send these words of appreciation regarding the school, and the careful teaching of Mr. Mesta.

Wishing you, Sir, Department, the season's compliments.

I pray you listen to a little bit of explanation how it is just to settle my guilt, but only to show you how all this came about. Sometimes before the end of last quarter, I began to feel tired and weak and often with pain in my stomach. J. Ogle Carse, Barrister, Ottawa, requests that the expenses incurred by Henry L. Masta, teacher of the Protestant School at Pierreville, in fitting up living quarters in the lower part of the school building and moving the classroom to the upper floor be paid.

The history of this case is, briefly, as follows. He, however, secured a contractor and proceeded with the work and, as you will remember, consulted you with a view to payment of the account. The cost of the alterations amounted to $98.71. Payment was refused on the ground that he had the work done without authority.

Mr. Carse requests that this claim be reconsidered and that the account for the repairs be paid. Our Agent has certified the account and the contractor has not yet been paid for his work. It is pointed out in Mr. Carse's letter that, as we have provided a teachers' residence for the Roman Catholic schools at Pierreville and Caughnawaga, we should provide living quarters for the teacher of the Protestant School at Pierreville.

While Mr. Masta undertook the work of having the alterations made without authority, yet, as he points out, if another teacher is secured at any time living quarters will be available as a result of the alterations made. I would, therefore, recommend favourable consideration of the payment of this account.

At the request of Mr. H. L. Marta and my own keen interest in the education of children I examined the St. Francis Indian School on above date. Having a Registered Teacher's Certificate needless to say I am fully qualified to present this report; and I respectfully submit the same to the Schools Department of Indian Affairs on the splendid work carried on, much to the credit of the teachers.

I found the building in very good condition as to repairs, and the interior, the model of cleanliness with neat little desks very suitable for their occupants. The ground is fenced round beautifully.

The work here is carried on with difficulty: 1. Some children return late in the fall and leave before the end of the school year, thus losing much valuable periods of instruction both at the opening and closing of the school year. This loss of time is almost irreparable, and a decided handicap to the children, and multiplication of work for the teacher. 2. Illness has seriously retarded the progress of one child. I found six children present.

The discipline was excellent and I have no hesitation in reporting that better could not be had anywhere. The writing of the children was bold and good, both in style and penmanship. The composition was fair, but rather too elementary for the ages of two of the
most advanced and biggest, girls.

I observed an air of timidity among them, although this should not be so, seeing I am always among them in my pastoral duty, and this timidity may account for not being quick in answering questions of grammar and general knowledge of what they read.

Another good considering the handicap enumerated above.

Their knowledge of the Scriptures was very good. This I gathered in teaching them in the Church School. History and Geography were fair, and commerce of Canada good.

On the whole the work is satisfactory seeing that the surroundings are such which do not tend to foster a vigorous educational growth.

The work of the school speaks very favourably for the tact and judgment exercised by the teacher in his work and duty of moulding and fashioning the youthful lives for future service.

Respectfully submitted by,

June 14, 1928.

On the above date I examined the scholars at the Odanak Protestant Elementary School at the request of Mr. H. L. Masta the schoolmaster.

I found that in the major subjects, reading writing and arithmetic the pupils displayed a marked ability and showed the results of careful teaching on the part of Mr. Masta.

The principal events in Canadian History and their significance to Canada have been carefully explained in such a manner that the young students could fully appreciate their importance and credit is due to their instructor.

In geography the class showed a fair knowledge of the boundaries of North America; the sources of the principal rivers and the position of the important lakes. The pupils answered readily to questions relating to the principal towns and cities of Quebec and gave reasons for their importance.

Attention has been given to scripture and the newer subject of hygiene has been touched upon, and with reference to the latter the neatness of the scholars and the cleanliness of the school show the practical application of the subject.

I was particularly pleased at the ability displayed in oral and written French and English, and as a university student can see readily that these important subjects have been carefully taught.

Finally, I consider that the school at Odanak compares very favourably with the standard adopted in the city elementary schools and the pupils show equal intelligence.

Donald Andrews, L.L.C.M., P.C.T.

Mr. Secretary,

Sir:

I have the honor to send you herewith the reports on my school, by Mr. Normand, the school inspector, and Mr. Andrews, student in charge of the Anglican church here, respectively.

My school closed on the 22nd inst., as all others in Yamaska, including the other one in the Reserve. From my past experience, I can truly say that it is practically impossible to keep one school open while the other one in the same locality is closed.

I am consciously well satisfied with my work when looking back. I see so many of my former pupils doing wonderfully well. They have good responsible positions and command money. They are either the wives or the husbands, as the case may be, of respectable American or French Canadian citizens. They are "des Sauvages" no more.

Another sign of the prosperity of this school is the constant fight waged against it by the anti-Anglican. It is only a few days since Mr. Normand, the school inspector, has enlisted to carry on this hostility. Mr. Desbengue, the curé, was overheard saying to Mr. Normand...
Normand: We have tried, in vain, again and again for a long time to cause the closing up of this little Protestant school which is a sore to this community, but I do believe that it would be closed and remain closed if you only helped us. There are, here, only three or four pupils at the present time and they are not members of the Band. Mr. Normand then promised to do all that is possible in their favour.

It is true that quite a few of my pupils who are members of the Band are away during this quarter but will be back next fall. The mother of those present is an Indian woman, born though up here, has never lived here. Her father and mother were both members of the Band. She owns some property in the Reserve. There are at least ten full-blooded French pupils and about as many half-breeds, not members of the Band, attending the R.C. School in the Reserve. The parents of the Indian pupils complain that their children do not get as much attention as the French pupils, but that is none of my business and would have nothing to do with it.

Respectfully submitted,

Your obedient servant,

By Henry L. Masta

at one time Presiding Chief of the Abenaki Indians at St. Francis, Canada; now teacher in the Dartmouth school on the Reservation.

Of the two hundred or more Indians who attended Moore's Charity School and Dartmouth College, not the least notable was the group which came from Canada. The Canadian regions had been traveled over by Frenchmen's explorers and teachers as early as 1700, and an account of the travels may be found in the Narragansetts. Several Indian boys were brought to Dartmouth by two teachers just previous to the Revolution, among them a member of the famous Gill family which had its origins from a Deerfield captive. Mr. Masta, who has taken up the Dartmouth succession as teacher on the Abenaki reservation (Dartmouth Indians having founded the school about the Nineteenth Century) writes for the Alumni Magazine a short account of these Indians who came to Dartmouth by canoe or horseback in the early days. The first Masta came to Dartmouth about 1809.

THE DARTMOUTH MEN

In reference to the men of this place (St. Francis, Canada) who were educated at Dartmouth, I beg to mention: Francis Annance, Daniel Katnash (Cartnanch), George Annance, Phillip Gill, Joseph A. Masta, John B. Masta, Peter Paul Osunkhirhine, alias Masta, and Simon Annance, but I would lay stress especially upon the last two, because, while those did wonderfully well in their several spheres, they did these goodly benefit of their education to their own people in their native land. Peter was a leader, and that also is the meaning of Osunkhirhine. He was the first Indian school teacher and minister of the Gospel here. He was about ninety years of age when he died and he had spent the first and best part of his life in teaching and managing his own people. He was interested in the education of all the young people of his tribe (Abenaki) but especially in that of his brothers Joseph and John Masta. He headed them to Dartmouth at Hanover, N.H., not so much by drawing along or going before as by instruction or counsel.

As the old saying goes: "An Indian is always ready when about to go on a journey—because he has nothing to pack up"—what he wears on his back is all that he carries. As for the Mastas they each had only a white blanket coat and toque with hawthorn prongs instead of buttons. They covered the whole distance on foot and they were amazed at their good reception, even as if they were rich. Everybody was good and kind to them. The students supplied them with clothing and shoes. The poor Indians in return did everything in their power to show their thankfulness while the invisible proof thereof was in their hearts never to be forgotten.

A PICTURESQUE CONTEST

On Friday morning the contestants from McGill, Vermont, Williams, New Hampshire, Massachusetts, Yale, Technology and Colgate had all arrived. Their brilliant costumes, new to snow-sports in New England, caught the eye on every hill and distant prospect. The scarlet of McGill with its coat of arms in white aroused the envy of feminine eyes. At three o'clock a thousand spectators had gathered on the wet snow on the Golf Links to watch this first intercollegiate meet. The realization that here were contestants from another nation rising up under the American and Canadian flags brought a spontaneous roar of welcome from the crowd.

The cross-country snowshoers were soon away on a three-mile course out through the Vale in deep snow that made the race a rather contested. Trick racing-shoes were barred, and all runners wore a 13-inch identical shoe. Three Dartmouth men came back first, W. D. Kipp '17, C. B. Thompson '17, and M. G. Sherburne '17. The cross-country ski race over a short course was won by C. H. Paulsen, New Hampshire State '15, who romped in minutes ahead of Birks of McGill and Bowler of Dartmouth. He followed this success an exhibition of somersaults from a jump on the line which thrilled the crowd and threw the movie men into a frenzy of attempts to follow through with the camera without forgetting to crank. Dick Bowler and Johnny Carleton of Hanover High School started the event with the bronchial leaps into space from the new jumps. The size of these younger lads compared to the length of their jumps seemed impossible to be true to those not accustomed to the prowess of sons of the faculty. A comical stunt-race down slides, through barrels and amongst potatoes from the foot of the take-off gave B. N. Davis, W. D. Kipp '17, and A. N. Andrews '16 prizes. This was called an Obstacle Race and entertained the crowd when the Dartmouth-McGill relayers were out of the picture. This relay race, begun too late to be finished the same day, was the second dual meet of a series begun at Shawbridge the year before. N. Williams of McGill came in first, followed by O. Mack '16, D. O. C. Rut. C. P. Hubert '15 and O. J. Frost '16 were able to overhaul W. L. Rutherford and G. Thomson of McGill for a substantial lead. The darkness ended the race at that point and it was postponed until Saturday.

In an Alumni Gymnasium transformed into a shadowy evergreen wood the Outing Club dance became the Carnival Ball. Formerly for the moment, members of the club had worked their magic to produce a fairy glade. Hidden by interlacing fir trees over the deck walls and chest weights; gone were the steel girders, lost in the forest night. The mad revelers wore their complicated intricacies of one step, hesitation, and maxixe around the giant symbolic pine which from the center of the scene dominated the glade. More than 100 couples were presented to the patronesses, who were the wives of the officers and faculty of the College. The officers of the club were the ushers. In a beautiful setting, carnival had danced in celebration of its new proportions.

A day of Hanover weather ushered in the second part of the competition and made fast going for all races. During the morning Bache-Wigg starting with a lead of 4.43 minutes over McLeod of McGill won the dual event while ski-relay. The dashes on skis were won by Dartmouth's five men of skill. In the hundreds N. Williamson, McGill, C. D. Horton '15 and J. P. Bowler '15 placed. In the furlong Opie Horton was first followed by the Hubberts, C. P. '15 and W. C. '18. In the snowshoeing L. D. Felton '18, W. D. Kipp '17, and M. G. Sherburne '17 in the first race, with Kipp, Sherburne and D. H. Reddick '17 in the second, shut out all of the Vermont runners. The crowd, now doubled in numbers, adjourned to the three new ski jumps for what was considered the cream of the sport. The dual meet between Dartmouth and McGill was the bone of contention, for no other team could even threaten that pair save the lone star of New Hampshire. In this contest McLeod won distance jump, 214.5, although Bache-Wigg jumped 65 feet, King 60 feet, McLeod, McGill, 58 feet in individual jumps. In the style of jumping Dartmouth won 556.3-492, with individual high ratings of 161.3 for W. T. King '17, 149.3 for G. Birks, McGill, and Bache-Wigg '15 145. In the distance open, Fisher of McGill jumped 60 feet, Bache-Wigg 59.8 and another of New Hampshire, in the style open, C. E. Frost '18, W. T. King '17 and J. Bache-Wigg '15 took all places for Dartmouth. Reddie of McGill received a special prize from Rev. John E. Johnson for the longest jump of 87 feet which was off the slope and beyond the landing hill. At the conclusion of the contest, Paulsen made a perfect somersault from the ski jump in the Vale, and landed successfully. This was the thrilling event of the day for the onlookers and served as the spur for many subsequent strivings on the part of many ski jumpers, little and big. Dartmouth had won the dual meet with McGill, and the intercollegiate meet. McGill was second and New Hampshire with her one man team was third.

In the evening the league basketball game with Yale was played in the Alumni Gymnasium to be followed by the Musical Clubs concert in Webster Hall. Ben W. Grills '15, president of the Outing Club, announced during intermission that Reverend J. E. Johnson '66 had presented the club with one thousand dollars as an expression of his desire to see the success of the carnival and of his desire that the activities of the club continue. This gift was the culmination of a year of generosity during which he had given the ski jump, toboggan chute, kiosk, funds for the pond work, and prizes for carnival.

Thus in five steps the Winter Carnival of the Dartmouth Outing Club had grown from a very small intramural contest to an occasion which was the final climax of the year, and which included an intercollegiate meet involving New England and Canada. It had drawn into its train all of the winter activities of the College and had become the pattern for many other carnivals in both the collegiate and civic world.

My mother's mother was Ursule Gill, and my father's mother Catherine Vassal. The Gills and Vassals intermarried. Samuel Gill and Miss James, two captives aged 14 and 10 years respectively, were brought here in 1711 from New England (according to reference to Mitchell's New General Atlas, County Map of Mass., Conn. and Rhode Island, 1864). The two captives were adopted by two women of the tribe as their own children and were treated with great kindness and affection. They soon picked up the Indian language, customs, manners. When they became of age to get married, the council decreed that the two couples should be joined together in matrimony in order to preserve the pure blood of their race and accordingly they were married. They never, after or before their marriage, manifested a desire to return to their parents. They both died here at St. Francis, he in 1738, and she twenty years previously.

There are over a thousand descendants from this family.

Mr. Vassal who married an Indian woman of this tribe was a colonel of the Carignan regiment, and my grandmother Catherine Vassal must have been his granddaughter. Stanislaus Vassal, Catherine's own brother, married Felicité Gill, the sister of my grandmother, Ursule Gill.

HISTORY OF THE ABENAKI

Odanak is the name of the Abenaki Indian village in St. Francis Reservation, near Pierreville, Yamaska Co., Province of Quebec, Canada. Odana means a village or city. Odanak means to or from the village or city. This place was formerly known as the mission of St. Francis de Sales. Abenaki from Woban-a-ki means Eastern land; woban is east or dawn; a is at or to, and ki is land; wobanakik is the people whose land is toward the east in reference to that of other tribes. The St. Francis Indians were also called Algonquins because they came from the Oyster River. Als or ela means oyster; also or ela means of oyster; guntekw means river. Aisiguntekw means Oyster River, which is very likely Ellis River, Maine.

By the treaty of Utrecht the King of France ceded to England all the territories of the Abenakis tribe of Indians, his faithful allies. The governor de Vaudrill when asked if this was not true replied that the possessions of Abenakis were not mentioned in the cession of land. The Abenakis nevertheless were deprived of their lands and had to choose either extermination or expulsion. They of course chose the latter. They left hesitatingly as they departed from their native land was a scene never forgotten, and to crown their misfortune as soon as they reached Canada, they were oppressed by the Algonquins who said:

"You are strangers. We do not want you here, and we will make a short story of you if you persist in occupying our lands."

However they were allowed to stay a few days on trial and fortunately the two nations became friends in the meantime.

The first settlement of the Abenakis in Canada was at St. Joseph de Sillery near Quebec, the second at Chaudiere, and third and last at St. Francis.

Mr. Gill married Ursule Osunkhirhine, a woman to whom were born two boys, George and Frank, and one girl Catherine. Catherine became the wife of Osunkhirhine to whom were born Peter, Louis and Mary. The husband died and his widow married Toussaint Masta, a Frenchman, whose children were Joseph, John, Adeline, Ignace, Peter Osunkhirhine, Joseph and John Masta, Noel and Simon Annance, and a few others were educated at Dartmouth College, N. H. Peter Osunkhirhine became an ordained minister of the Congregational church and was the father of the protestant faith here. Joseph Masta was a physician; John Masta a surgeon; Noel Annance, a professor of languages; Simon Annance, a school teacher; I am the son of Ignace and am the present school teacher at Odanak. I have held that position many years.
The Story of an Indian

By Samson Occom

When Samson Occom came back to America after his trip abroad he decided that it would be the best thing possible for him to write his autobiography. He tells the story of his life and then goes on to make a complaint against his treatment by the missionary board. This paper is in two parts, and will be divided between two numbers before the actual journal is carried on again. In point of time the writing of the narrative follows directly after the trip to England, but the details he writes of go back some forty years previous.

The Reasons for the Autobiography

Having seen and heard several representations in England and Scotland by some gentlemen in America concerning me, and finding many gross mistakes in their account, I thought it my duty to give a short, plain and honest account of myself that those who may hereafter see it may know the truth concerning me, that it is against my mind to give a history of myself and publish it whilst I am still alive, yet to do justice to myself and to those who may desire to know something concerning me, and for the honor of religion, I will venture to give a short narrative of my life.

S. Occum

FROM MY BIRTH TILL I RECEIVED THE CHRISTIAN RELIGION

I was born a heathen and brought up in heathenism till I was between 16 and 17 years of age, at a place called Mohegan in New London Connecticut in New England. My parents lived a wandering life, as did all the Indians at Mohegan. They chiefly depended upon hunting, fishing and fowling for their living, and had no connection with the English excepting to trade with them, in their small trifles, and they strictly maintained and followed their heathenish ways, customs, and religions, so there was some preaching among them; once a fortnight a minister from New London used to come up, and the Indians to attend; not that they regarded the Christian religion but they had blankets...

Dear Sir,

Mr. Mata, teacher at the protestant school at Odanak is sick and according to the information I got he will not be able to resume his teaching. Would it not be wiser to consider if the moment has not come to close that school at least until there are a sufficient number of pupils to justify its maintenance. Dear Sir:

I herewith respectfully beg leave to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 1st inst., and at the same time to express my great surprise at the decision arrived at to close the C.E. School of which I am the teacher, at a time when things are O.K., and at a time too, when I expected a greater clemency than ever before, because of my misfortune. I spent most of my summer holidays in the Civic Hospital, having undergone two grave operations within three weeks, which cost me nearly $500. I am now all right to teach school, but not able to do any manual labour. I think my old age and my thirty-one years of faithful service should also be taken into consideration. There is no provision made for the support of old teachers, but being the only one throughout Canada who have served 31 years as school teacher, the Government might well grant me a pension equal to a half of my salary, for the rest of my days or at least allow me to continue my work, as long as I am efficiently able.

There are now 9 pupils on the roll, 7 of whom attend school regularly.

Dear Mr. Masta:

I have your letter of the 8th instant, enquiring concerning the possibilities of a pension. I regret that there is no provision for the superannuation of teachers in Indian schools. I may say, however, that the Department can give a small gratuity to teachers who have given lengthy service - two months' salary being allowed upon retirement. My dear Mr. Scott:

Many thanks for your sympathetic letter regarding the Indian children on the Reserve at St. Francis Village.

Of course the younger children will soon be growing into school age, and there is no Boarding School near our Reserve. As far as I can make out we have no Anglican Boarding School nearer than the Mohawk Reserve, or the Sault, and that would be a very expensive thing to transfer the children there and back to their own Reserve for the holidays. It would be much cheaper for the Department to keep the Day School on the Reserve. We certainly have not enough children to warrant a Boarding School near by.

What suggestion would you make regarding the children going to Boarding School? The parents might object to their going far away. Somebody would have to go with them, and altogether it seems to me a much more expensive proposition for the Department than to maintain a Day School on the Reserve even if it be only for a few children.

THE BELL OF ATRI

The king of Atri built a tall tower and hung a big bell in it. A long rope hung from the bell to the ground. "If any one does you a wrong, ring this bell," said the king, "then I shall know that some one needs help."

Many people rang the bell—rich people and poor people, big people and little people. But at length
the rope was worn off till a man could hardly reach it. Some person, passing by, saw this and mended it with a long grape-vine.

Not far from the town lived a faithful old horse. He had worked for his master many years, and now he was too old to work any more. This unkind man would not feed him, but turned him out on the street to starve.

The poor horse wandered about until he saw the grape-vine. He was hungry and tried to eat it. This made the bell ring, and the king came to see who needed help. When he saw the starving horse, he sent for his master.

"This poor horse has served you well many years," said the king. "He is old now and cannot work. You must take him back to his stable, and feed and care for him for the rest of his life."

Then was the man ashamed, but he led home the horse and did as the king had ordered.

I, the undersigned, was the head-chief for twenty consecutive years; school-teacher for thirty-one years; have been for many years and I am still the church warden and secretary-treasurer at St. Francis Reserve.

I was first appointed to take charge of the church of England-school here in 1873. The average attendance was then 15. We had no school-house and no equipment. I received $100.00 per annum from the New Colonial Church and School Society of London, Eng., which enabled me to procure a room and fuel for the school. Things went on so, for three or four years. I then made application to the Government for a school-teacher's salary and received a grant of $100.00 per annum, but in a year or two the charity of the school-society was withdrawn and my salary was reduced to only $100.00 per annum as before; in the next two years, however, it was increased by $51.00 each year, my salary therefore was $200.00 per annum in 1883, when I quit teaching. It was what some people called a starvation salary and it really was so, but I did not mind it because I was interested in the education of my own people, irrespective of their creed. Memorandum:

Mr. BURKARD,

With further reference to your memorandum of the 31st ultimo, regarding the request of Right Reverend Dr. Farthing, Bishop of Montreal, for the reopening of the St. Francis Anglican Indian Day School on the Pierreville reserve No. 12, in the federal district of Yamaska, I have now to inform you that a report has been received from the local Indian Agent, giving the names of the Protestant families on the reserve and the names and ages of their children.

Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Benedict have 8 children, varying in ages from 1 to 12 years. Of this number, three are enrolled at the Mohawk Institute, Brantford, Ont., leaving only two of school age, viz.: Florence, 11 years; and Francis, 6 years. The three youngest children of this family are under school age.

Mr. and Mrs. Fred Watson have four children, varying in ages from 1 to 6 years. Only one of these children, the eldest, is of school age.

Mary Lagrave has a child one year old.

Besides the above, there is a family of half-breeds, viz.: Mr. and Mrs. Walter Hoff. There are 9 children in this family, from 8 months to 17 years of age. Four of these children are in residence at the Chapleau Indian Residential School, leaving at home George - 17 years; Gladys - 6; Priscilla - 4; Margene - 3; Ellen - 2 months. It will be noted that George is
over school age and there is only one other child, Gladys, at home of school age.

While the Department is under no obligation to provide educational facilities for half-breeds, this family have resided on the reserve for a number of years, living the Indian mode of life and the Department has undertaken the education of the children. For this reason, four of the children of this family were placed in the Chapleau Indian Residential School.

From the above information, it will be seen that there remain only four Protestant children of school age on the reserve - hardly a sufficient number to incur the expense of conducting a school.

As pointed out in my memorandum above referred to, the re-establishment of the school would be difficult, as it would be necessary to obtain the consent of the Treasury Board to increase establishment before the services of a teacher could be engaged. As vacancies occur, arrangements could be made to have the few Protestant children, as they arrive at school age, placed in residential schools.

Deputy Superintendent General.

The question of protestant children attending the catholic school of the Rev. Sisters on the reserve was discussed thoroughly with Mr. Benedict, father of the only protestant children who could follow the school. Mr. Benedict objected to his children going to the catholic school because he intimated, other children were calling names to his offsprings, vile beast names, and that the latter were submitted to bad treatment in the past. JOINT MEMORANDUM

Le mélange de croiser les religions dans les écoles est une idée de mauvaise nature et doit être abandonné. On entend que l'enseignement protestant donne un meilleur cours de la langue anglaise que nos religieux.
enseignants; cette institution est jeune et ne suffit pas à la charge de l'entretien. Nous avons ici dans la réserve une académie dirigée par des religieuses enseignantes et d'autres religieux qui ont une bonne réputation dans l'enseignement de diverses matières, de français et d'anglais, et cela avec tant de succès qu'à tous les ans, plusieurs familles canadiennes de Pierreville sont affluées pour y placer leurs enfants. Un autre établissement de cette nature, c'est que nos religieuses sont dans une position difficile; le monde refuse la méthode concrète employée à un enfant lorsque chez les parents du même âge, tout enfant de l'éducation catholique peut être placé à l'école publique. C'est bien de choisir une méthode plus longtemps.

Je vous prie de me faire part de votre avis sur le sujet de la question qui demande de donner des instructions relatives à l'article 18 de l'état des Sauvages, et cela par le bon ordre qui doit exister dans la Tribu.

Voici tout détaillé,

Charles Notette, Chef.

CIRCULAIRE
DE
MONSIEUR L'EVEQUE DE NICOLET
aux fidèles de la
Mission Catholique des Abenakis d'Odanak

Eveche de Nicolet,
le 23 Fevrier 1935.

Nos Très Chers Frères,

Des circonstances inquiétantes qui existent dans votre tribu présentement, nous imposent le devoir de vous rappeler, encore une fois, l'enseignement de l'Eglise sur les écoles non catholiques, tel que donné par les saints Canons, nos Conciles provinciaux, le Premier Concile plénier de Québec, et la voix des Papes, de même que la défense qu'elle fait aux parents et à leurs enfants, concernant la fréquentation de ces écoles, sans l'autorisation préalable de l'Eveque du lieu.

Voici quel est cet enseignement, et qu'elle est cette défense; gravez-les bien dans votre mémoire, et n'oubliez pas que vous êtes catholiques, et que vous devez obéir à l'Eglise, votre mère;

I.--Enseignement religieux.

a).-Les fidèles doivent, dès leur enfance, recevoir un enseignement religieux, où la religion et la morale aient la part principale, et d'où soit banni tout ce qui serait contraire à la religion et à la morale. Canon 1372, par. I.

b).-Les parents et leurs représentants ont le droit et le devoir de
grave de procurer à leurs enfants une éducation chrétienne.-Canon I372 par.2

c).-Dans toute école élémentaire, un enseignement religieux approprié à l'âge des enfants doit être donné.-Canon I373, par.1.

II.-Écoles.-

a).-Les enfants catholiques ne doivent pas fréquenter les écoles antireligieuses, neutres ou mixtes, c'est-à-dire, les écoles qui sont ouvertes aux protestants.

L'Ordinaire du lieu (L'Eveque) seul doit juger, en se conformant aux instructions du Saint-Siège, dans quelles circonstances, tout danger de perversion étant écarté, peut être tolérée la fréquentation de ces écoles.

Canon I374.

b).-Quelle crainte doivent avoir les parents catholiques d'un instituteur ou d'une institutrice dont les sentiments et la conduite ne sont pas franchement catholiques.-Mandement des Pères du IVème Concile de Québec.

c).-Nous jugeons tout-a-fait dangereuses les écoles mixtes, c'est-à-dire, les écoles où les enfants catholiques admis avec les enfants protestants ne reçoivent aucune instruction religieuse ou reçoivent l'enseignement d'une fausse religion.-Ist Concile de Québec, décret XVIIème.

d).-Les parents qui permettent à leurs enfants de fréquenter les écoles non catholiques, ne peuvent être absous, si après avoir été avertis ils continuent leur même manière de faire, à moins qu'ils n'aient obtenu préalablement la permission de l'Eveque.-Vème Concile de Québec, décret XVème.

e).-Le septième Concile de Québec renouvelle la défense qui a été faite par le 5ème Concile de Québec, sous peine de refus des sacrements, d'envoyer les enfants catholiques à des écoles protestantes, ou non catholiques, sans la permission de l'Eveque.

f).-Le Premier Concile Plenier de Québec, a son tour, condamne énergiquement, en s'appuyant sur la doctrine de l'Eglise, et les paroles des Papes Pie
Papes Pie IX et Leon XIII, ces mêmes écoles neutres ou mixtes, c'est-à-dire les écoles non catholiques. Et nous savons tous avec quelle force le Pape glorieusement régnant, Sa Sainteté Pie XI, chaque fois que l'occasion s'en est présentée, a mis les Catholiques en garde contre les dangers de perversions que comporte la fréquentation des écoles non-catholiques.

III.-Conclusion

Or, N.T.C.F. ?AUCUN PARENT PARMI VOUS, de même qu'aucun enfant parmi vous, n'a la permission à l'Eveque exigée ici par l'Eglise, et cette permission Nous jugeons en conscience qu'il n'y a aucune raison de l'accorder à qui que ce soit parmi vous, ni aux parents, ni aux enfants; Conséquemment, Nous refusons de l'accorder. Nous considérons que votre Couvent, sous la direction de nos Chères Soeurs Grises de la Croix, répond à tous vos besoins et à toutes les exigences puisqu'il a réussi à faire de votre Tribu jusqu'ici l'une des plus distinguées et des plus instruites des Tribus indiennes au pays, et que plusieurs de ses anciens élèves sont actuellement très bien placés, quoiqu'ils n'aient appris l'anglais qu'à ce Couvent bénit.

D'ailleurs, vous le comprenez comme Nous, N.T.C.F. ?Si l'Eveque donnait cette permission à l'un, comment pourrait-il la refuser à l'autre?

Veuillez le croire il ne s'agit pas d'une affaire de fanatisme, mais bien d'une affaire de conscience imperissable et pour l'Eveque et pour le Missionnaire, et vous ne sauriez douter de notre parole.

Est-il besoin d'ajouter qu'il ne vous est pas permis d'avoir en votre possession, et encore moins, de les lire, des livres dont la doctrine n'est pas catholique, ou qui attaquent, d'une façon ou d'une autre, l'Eglise catholique, à laquelle vous avez le bonheur d'appartenir. Vous avez la foi, ne vous exposez pas à la perdre.

Vous connaissez, N.T.C.F., le vif intérêt que Nous vous portons, et Nous sommes heureux de reconnaître que jusqu'ici vous nous avez toujours donné
confiance et respect, en suivant Notre direction; C'est notre espoir que vous Nous écoutez encore aujourd'hui, et que vous tiendrez compte de Nos présentes instructions et recommandations.

Et enfin que Dieu vous éclaire dans votre foi de Catholique, Nous le prions de combler et vos familles et vos personnes de ses bénédictions les plus abondantes et les plus précieuses.

Sera la présente lettre-circulaire lue au prone de la Messe Conven-
tuelle, le premier dimanche après sa réception.

J.S. HERMANN.
Évêque de Nicolet.
