Dear Sir,

Some time ago Miss Moodie recommended that Mrs. Emmett might undertake teaching the girls in your school the rudiments of domestic science, sewing, etc. She was informed that until we had knowledge of your own activities with the boys of your school no consideration could be given to providing other assistance. The matter was again brought to my attention a month ago and on October 7th we wrote you asking you to advise us what work is being done in your school along the lines of manual training. You were also asked to notify us what additional supplies you required.

Although almost a month has elapsed no reply has been received from you. Please report immediately whether or not you have undertaken any manual training or basketry instruction for the pupils in your school.

Yours very truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

A. Emmett, Esq.,
Teacher,
St. Frances C.E. Indian Day School,
Odanak, Que.
Ottawa, January 18, 1938.

Dear Sir:

May I refer to departmental letters dated October 7, 1938, and November 1, 1938, to neither of which this Branch has received a reply.

Mr. W. H. Brady, in a report submitted to the Department immediately following the inspection of your school states:

"on the report form I have indicated the subjects for which no authorized text books or teacher's manuals have been supplied. There are some text books which have been discontinued for at least two years. The teacher, Mr. Emmett, stated that he had supplied the Agent with a list of text books needed but had not received any."

I may state by way of comment the records here indicate that all text books requested for use at the Odanak C. E. School have been supplied promptly by this Branch. There is nothing on file to indicate that you have been refused text books or school supplies at any time.

A number of reports have reached me during the last year with respect to your work at the Odanak School. These reports indicated that your work was in no sense satisfactory. I was particularly anxious, however, not to be harsh or unfair to you in any sense; consequently I had Inspector Brady inspect the school and submit to this Branch a special report on your work. I note the

Inspector's -

A. Emmett, Esq.,
Teacher,
St. Francis C.E. Indian Day School,
Odanak, Quebec.
Inspector's report indicates that discipline, school management, preparation of lessons, community service and pupils' progress are particularly faulty. It is my duty to warn you therefore that it is not the intention of this Branch to keep in the service incompetent teachers, and it is certainly not our intention to employ teachers who refuse to reply to departmental correspondence. Unless I have an immediate reply to this letter and an explanation as to why you refuse to reply to the letters already mentioned, I shall have no alternative but to ask the Treasury Branch to suspend your monthly payments.

Yours very truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Ottawa, January 18, 1935

Dear Sir:

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your report on the inspection of the St. Francis Church of England Indian Day School, Odanak, Quebec.

I am enclosing herewith, for your information, copy of the letter sent forward to The Honourable Cyrille Delage. I should like to direct your attention particularly to the last paragraph of that communication.

I must express regret that I did not succeed in communicating with you prior to your visit to Odanak. A number of reports had reached me to the effect that the work of the teacher in charge of the school there was in many respects unsatisfactory. I wrote to the teacher on October 7, 1934, intimating to him that this Branch would be glad to supply him with tools, text books, etc., suitable for the promotion of handicraft work and vocational instruction at his school. Mr. Emmett did not reply to this letter. I wrote to him again on November 1, 1935, and suggested that if he were willing the Branch would be prepared to employ his wife with the object of giving the girls at the school an elementary course in domestic science. Mr. Emmett again failed to reply to this letter, and recently I heard that he was not interested in departmental letters and that it was not his intention to reply to either of the communications.

The records here indicate that Mr. Emmett's requests for school supplies, text books, etc., have always been met promptly by this Branch. There is not a vestige of evidence on file to suggest that the teacher at any time requested -

W. H. Brady, Esq.,
Inspector of Schools,
4222 Old Orchard Ave.,
Montreal, Que.
requested text books or school supplies that were refused.

It would be impossible for a teacher to behave in the sense that Mr. Emmett has behaved in a public school and still retain his position. In the Western Provinces when a teacher refuses to answer departmental correspondence the government grant to that school is suspended. I was very anxious however not to be unfair to this particular teacher - hence my request for a thorough inspection of his work at the school.

May I embrace this opportunity to thank you for your prompt action in undertaking, at our request, the inspection of this school.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Ottawa, July 6, 1939.

Dear Sir:

I regret that you were not at home when I visited the Pierreville Agency on the 23rd ultimo. At that time I called at the St. Francis C.E. School and spent some time with the teacher.

From the information that he gave me, I feel that he is fully qualified to handle a school of this size, but it is quite apparent that he is not taking as great an interest in the work as he should. However, it has been decided to continue his services during the academic year 1939-40, on the understanding that he makes a real effort to improve his work. He is being written to that effect, and the Department will expect you to give him every possible co-operation.

Regarding the repairs to the building, the teacher mentioned a new floor. Personally, I cannot see any reason why we should expend money in replacing the floor. It appears to be in good condition, but apparently had not been washed for some time. Please make immediate enquiries and advise me what it would cost to redecorate the interior of the classroom.

The teacher also mentioned that there is a window back of the blackboard, which has not been properly boarded up, and as a result he states the building is very cold in the winter. You might let me know the approximate cost of having this window boarded up and a new window placed on one side of the building.

The teacher complains about the roof, but it was pouring rain the day I visited the school and no water was coming through, so I do not feel that we would be justified in making any expenditure in this connection. The painting of the exterior of the building will have to stand until later, as no funds are available.

Benj. Maurault, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Pierreville, P.Q.
I will expect to hear from you at an early date regarding the repairs which I suggest be carried out during the present holiday period.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Ottawa, July 7, 1939.

Dear Mr. Emmett:

Indian Agent Maurault is being instructed to obtain prices for decorating the interior of the classroom, also boarding up the window behind the blackboard and putting a new window on one side of the school.

I did not see any great necessity for replacing the floor. It appears to be in fairly good condition but apparently had not been washed for some time.

From the information you gave me, I feel that you are well qualified to handle the school. I felt, however, that you had apparently lost heart and were not devoting as much energy as could be expected.

The Department is anxious that the children attending your school receive every reasonable advantage along educational lines, and during the academic year 1939-40 we will expect you to put forth a great deal better effort than apparently you have done recently.

While the classroom is sufficiently large for the number of pupils in attendance, I must say that it did not have a very attractive appearance. Redecorating this room should help, and in addition the Department will forward to you a picture of the King and Queen, as well as a number of other pictures, which you can have the boys frame as part of their vocational training activity and hang these pictures in the classrooms.

I will look forward to visiting your school.

A. Emmett, Esq.,
Teacher,
St. Francis C.E. Indian Day School,
Odanak, Que.
during the academic year 1939-40. At such time I trust there will be evidenced a distinct improvement. Otherwise the Department will be obliged to dispense with your services at the end of June, 1940.

29th September 1941.

The Hon. T.A. Crerar,
Minister of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

My dear Mr. Crerar:

For many years the Diocese of Montreal has been specially interested in a little group of non-Roman Catholic Indians at Odanak, Que. We have been ministering to them in their small church Sunday by Sunday. This has been done at considerable expense but we have been glad to do it.

I am writing to ask if it would be possible for the Department to give us even a little financial assistance for the carrying on of this work. With the many other demands made upon the resources of our people it is not easy for the church to secure funds for such missionary work. A grant of even $300.00 a year would be of tremendous assistance to us and would enable us without difficulty to carry on our ministrations to these people.

There is another thing which causes us some concern and that is that I have learned of the resignations of Mr. Emmett, the school teacher of that little Protestant group and so far I believe no successor to him has been appointed. Would it be possible to have this matter looked into and some provision made for the proper instruction of that small group of Indian Protestant children?

I assure you that I will appreciate greatly anything that you can do in this matter.

Yours very truly,

(signed) ARTHUR MONTREAL
Ottawa, October 4, 1941.

My dear Bishop Carlisle:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of September 20, in which you seek information with respect to the operation of the Indian day school at Pierreville, Que., and assistance that might be secured from the Department for the promotion of missionary work amongst the Indians on the Pierre-ville reserve.

I regret to state that the Government has never at any time contributed to missionary effort amongst the Indians of Canada, nor is it possible to make such contributions from the appropriations voted by Parliament from year to year for the Indian service.

The records here indicate that the Indian day school at Pierreville had at the close of the last academic year an enrolment of 10 pupils and an average attendance of 8. We have not at this date succeeded in securing the services of a fully qualified teacher to take charge of this school; in fact there are at this date five Indian day schools for which we have failed to secure teachers. Should you be in a position to nominate a fully qualified teacher to take charge of this school, such action on your part would be very much appreciated by the officials of the Indian Affairs Branch. Mr. Emmett, who resigned from the position of teacher at this school a few months ago and whose work in many respects was far from satisfactory, was paid salary at the rate of $585.00 a year.

Yours sincerely,

Right Rev. Arthur Carlisle, D.D.,

Mr. Michel Tetreault, Indian Agent, Pierreville, Que.,

I have your letter of the 28th ultimo, with reference to the building formerly used as a Church of England Day School in the Pierreville agency.

I have reviewed several files and find that this school is the property of the Department even though we may not have spent much money in erecting it. We have kept it in repair for several years and as far as I can ascertain the land on which it is built was bought by the Indian Affairs Branch.

If the building is allowed to stand idle much longer it will probably be useless. Consequently, if you consider that the amount of $6.00 a month is sufficient rent we have no objection to renting it to Robert Sioui provided that he is willing to make the repairs mentioned in the second paragraph of your letter at his own expense. Please let me hear from you with regard to this matter.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Pierreville, August 9th, 1945.

Re: Church of England Day School.

Dear Sir:

Robert Sioui has just left my office and we have discussed the renting of this school. The amount of $6.00 a month is sufficient if we consider the repairs Sioui intends to do. The house rents are not very high here in Odanak. This school house will make a tenement of only 4 rooms.

There are 12 or 15 desks and 2 blackboards to dispose of. Would it be a good idea to bring them to the R.C. school where shelter is available? The Sisters say they can use the blackboards right now.

Regarding collection of the rent, I suppose I am the one designated to do it and forward it to the Receiver General covered with Form I.A.527, Credited to Abenaki Band.

Sioui is willing to pay the rent in advance.

Yours truly,

Dear Sirs:

As you are aware the Diocese of Montreal has been ministering to the St. Francis' Indian Mission for many years. The Reverend Thomas Ligget, Rector of Sorel, is the present Incumbent. The school question is a source of some concern. There are nine children, from 5 to 14 years of age, belonging to four families. In the past when numbers declined some children went to Chapleau but both children and parents felt the long separation very deeply and, as I understand, the cost of any return to their homes during the school period had to be met by the parents.

A possible solution was put before me recently wherein a teacher, at present in Sorel, might have been willing to undertake the position of teacher at the Mission. That, however, has not been found possible.

I can readily appreciate the high cost of reestablishing a regular school for such a small number of children. Alternatively it means that the children will be forced to attend the Roman Catholic Convent or, if they are sent to Chapleau, they are cut off from their home for a long period of time because, even if they are permitted to return from time to time, the cost of such travel is beyond the means of their families.

In view of the saving to the Department in not maintaining a school at the Mission, could any consideration be given to the question of making it possible for the children to return occasionally at less cost to their parents in the event of their being sent to Chapleau?

Yours sincerely,

Mr. Benj. Marault, M.D.
Indian Agent,
Pierreville.

Sir:

I, the undersigned ex Head-Chief of the Abenakis Band of Indians for twenty consecutive years; Church Warden and Secretary Treasurer for many years and school teacher for thirty one years, at St. Francis reserve, in my own name, in the name of the Church of England Congregation and in the name of the pupils hitherto attending the C.E. School here do hereby protest against the use of our school house for any other purpose than for school and prayer meetings. It is our school house. It was built for us by Anglicans. It is true that it was repaired and maintained in good condition by the Government but the money spent for that purpose was not a loan. As far as the land is concerned, I may say that it was never surrendered and it is not worth while to speak about it, as it cost only $14.00.

The equipment of the school is supplied by the Government but I pray the Superintendent of Indian Education to leave it with us, for sooner or later and before long, some religious society will be interested in us and will give us a teacher without pay, the same as when I first started to teach. The Colonial Church and School Society of London, England gave me $100.00 per annum to teach here, with which I was able to furnish a room and fuel for the school and things went on so for three or four years. There may be and there will be some other society that will do the same as the one above mentioned and I am sure that there will be some other man that will do the same as I did.

In the course of time the Sabrevois Mission Society built us a school house, which is the one we have now.

I am sending you under separate cover a picture of said school house, of my pupils and myself.

Your obedient servant,

(Signed) H. L. Mata.
Ottawa, October 25, 1947.

Please let me know when you have taken this action.

Sir:

I, the undersigned, ex. Head-chief of the Abenaki Band of Indians for twenty consecutive years, church-warden and secretary-treasurer for many years and school teacher for thirty-one years at St. Francis reserve, in my own name, in the name of the Church of England congregation and in the name of the pupils hitherto attending the C.E. school here do hereby protest against the use of our school-house for any other purpose than for school and prayer meetings. It is our school house. It was built for us by Anglicans. It is true that it was repaired and maintained in good condition by the Government but the money spent for that purpose was not a loan. As far as the land is concerned, I may say that it was never surrendered and it is worth while to speak about it, as it cost only $14.00.

The equipment of the school is supplied by the Government but I pray the Superintendent of Indian Education to leave it with us, for sooner or later and before long, some religious society will be interested in us and will give us a teacher without pay, the same as when I first started.
started to teach. The colonial church school society of London Eng. gave me $145.2 per annum to teach there, with which I was able to furnish a room and fuel for the school and things went on as for thirty or four years. There may be and there will be some other society that will do the same as the one above mentioned and I am sure that there will come other men that will do the same as I did.

In the course of time the Cadoreois Mission Society built us a school house, which is the one we have now.

I am sending you under separate cover a picture of said school house, of my pupils & myself.

The Hon. T.A. Crerar,
Minister of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir-

There is in my Diocese the Indian Mission School of St. Francis at Odanak. Our clergyman at Sorel, the Reverend R. Emmett, came to see me the other day and told me that conditions in that school were very far from satisfactory. Representations were made to the Department of Indian Affairs some months ago by a Mr. Brady of the Protestant Board. Certain repairs to the building are very badly needed, and one case of a child who was in need of spectacles which were ordered months ago, has not yet received any attention. The Mission Schools under the same department at Oka and Cashmere also seem to be receiving generous consideration. Their teachers are paid higher salaries and are given an allowance for rent and fuel, but no such help is given to the master of St. Francis' School.

Would it be possible for you to have someone review the whole situation and see if some consideration might be given which would result in the desired improvement in school conditions on that Reserve?

I remain,

Yours very sincerely,

sgd) Arthur Montreal
Ottawa, June 17, 1939.

My dear Bishop Carlisle:

I have for acknowledgment Your Lordship's letter of June 15, in which you seek information with respect to the operation of the St. Francis Church of England Indian Day School, Odanak, Quebec.

The records here indicate that the St. Francis school at Odanak was closed on September 30, 1920. Educational facilities on the Pierreville reserve were carefully reviewed at that time and it was discovered that there were not on the reserve a sufficient number of Indian pupils to justify the Department in keeping the school open for operation. It would appear, however, that one or two Indian families on the reserve continued to demand the re-opening of the school, with the result that the school was opened by my predecessor the Honourable Mr. Murphy in September, 1934. At that time a number of Indian pupils who had been enrolled at Anglican residential schools were brought back and provided with instruction at the day school.

At this date there is an enrolment at the school of twelve pupils and an average attendance during the last quarter of 9.6. Of these 12 pupils three are half-breeds and should be provided with instruction by the Provincial Government. They are in no sense the responsibility of this Department. It is the opinion of the officials that five of the remaining pupils should be provided with institutional care at an Anglican residential school. The mother

Right Reverend Arthur Carlisle, D.D.,
Bishop of Montreal,
1401 University Street,
Montreal, P. Q.
of these children died three months ago.

I note with interest your reference to the special inspection of this school, made by Mr. Brady. This inspection was undertaken in response to requests that had reached the Department from individuals who took the position that the work of the teacher was in many respects wholly unsatisfactory, and I am enclosing herewith, for your information, copy of the letter sent forward to the Inspector immediately following his report on the St. Francis school. The subject matter of this letter, you will note, is self-explanatory.

In view of all the circumstances, it has occurred to me that it might be advisable to have conditions on the Pierreville reserve, and particularly conditions at the St. Francis school, investigated by one of the senior officials of the Department. I am, therefore, issuing instructions to have the Chief of the Training Division visit Odanak toward the end of next week. This official will be instructed to make a thorough investigation of existing conditions and recommend what steps should be taken to provide educational facilities for the children of the Anglican Church now resident on the reserve. Just as soon as this report reaches me, I shall be glad to communicate with you again.

I regret to state that it is impossible for me to deal with the case of the girl who appears to be in need of glasses, referred to by Your Lordship in your communication. If the name of this girl is sent forward, I can assure you the case will be dealt with promptly. I should state, however, that on May 17 the Indian Agent was authorized by the Department to purchase two pairs of glasses for two residents of Odanak. It is just possible that the girl referred
to by you was supplied with glasses at that time.

May I embrace this opportunity to thank Your Lordship for your interest in these matters and for the courtesy that prompted you to bring them to my personal attention.

Yours sincerely,

Ottawa, July 6, 1929.

Dear Sir:

I regret that you were not at home when I visited the Pierreville agency on the 23rd ultimo. At that time I called at the St. Francis C. E. School and spent some time with the teacher.

From the information that he gave me, I feel that he is fully qualified to handle a school of this size, but it is quite apparent that he is not taking as great an interest in the work as he should. However, it has been decided to continue his services during the academic year 1929-40, on the understanding that he makes a real effort to improve his work. He is being written to that effect, and the Department will expect you to give him every possible co-operation.

Regarding the repairs to the building, the teacher mentioned a new floor. Personally, I cannot see any reason why we should expend money in replacing the floor. It appears to be in good condition, but apparently had not been washed for some time. Please make immediate enquiries and advise me what it would cost to redecorate the interior of the classroom.

The teacher also mentioned that there is a window back of the blackboard, which has not been properly boarded up, and as a result he states the building is very cold in the winter. You might let me know the approximate cost of having this window boarded up and a new window placed on one side of the building.

The teacher complains about the roof, but

Benj. Maurault, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Pierreville, P. Q.
it was pouring rain the day I visited the school and no water was coming through so I do not feel that it would be justified in making an expenditure in this connection. The painting of the exterior of the building will have to stand until later, as no funds are available.

I will expect to hear from you at an early date regarding the repairs which I suggest be carried out during the present holiday period.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Ottawa, July 7, 1939.

Dear Mr. Emmett:

Indian Agent Maurault is being instructed to obtain prices for decorating the interior of the classroom, also boarding up the window behind the blackboard and putting a new window on one side of the school.

I did not see any great necessity for replacing the floor. It appears to be in fairly good condition but apparently had not been washed for some time.

From the information you gave me, I feel that you are well qualified to handle the school. I felt, however, that you had apparently lost heart and were not devoting as much energy as could be expected.

The Department is anxious that the children attending your school receive every reasonable advantage along educational lines, and during the academic year 1939-40 we will expect you to put forth a great deal better effort than apparently you have done recently.

While the classroom is sufficiently large for the number of pupils in attendance, I must say that it did not have a very attractive appearance. Redecorating this room should help, and in addition the Department will forward to you a picture of the King and Queen, as well as a number of other pictures, which you can have the boys frame as part of their vocational training activity and hang these pictures in the classrooms.

I will look forward to visiting your school -

Sir:

The Protestant members of the band have decided to have the repairs made to their school-house which were authorized by your letter No. 152,859-5 dated the 13th June, 1902.

To begin with, they think fit to buy for the sum of fifty dollars a site belonging to Robert Paquette, Sr., situated in the centre of the village at the intersection of the four principal roads which traverse the village; this site is a little irregular in form; it is 24 feet on one side; 25 feet on another side, and 53 feet on the two other sides; there is on it a small house, old and almost uninhabitable.

If you desire to be instructed more exactly with regard to the position of this site, be good enough to consult the plan of the reserve prepared by Mr. C. G. DuBerger in 1897; the site is situated on the north side of the public road, opposite the Adventist Church, indicated on the plan by the No. 10.

Now the Protestant members ask the Department if the choice of this site to which to remove their school is approved, and, if so, to name someone who shall be authorized by the Department to make the purchase of this land, for and in the name of the Protestant members of the band, and to make a notarial contract with the vendor.

Allow me to suggest to the Department that either the Protestant Missionary, Rev. H. O. Loiselle, should be named, or the truant Officer of the Protestant School, Mr. H. L. Masta, ex-Chief.

As the season is advanced and time presses, an immediate reply from the Department will much oblige.

Your, etc.,
A. O. Comire,

My dear Mr. Hinton,

I have learned that an application has been made to the Crown for a piece of land at Bemerville for the purpose of a Protestant Separate School. For years past a school has been maintained for Protestant Indians at Bemerville under the direction of the Church of England Mission. Now, and on its property, the erection of another school is so small a community can only lead to inefficiency & trouble.

On representations of the Indians as to the situation of the school, I am willing to allow of its removal to another site, on condition (in accordance with the instructions of the Indians themselves) that the title of the school house be removed & the property on which it was placed shall remain with the Church of England as at present.

I therefore ask that the proposal be not assented to nor the deed be accepted by the Crown.

OTTAWA, 14th April, 1903:

The Deputy Superintendent General:

With further reference to the proposed removal of the Protestant school at Pierreville, I beg to say that a deed of the proposed new site from Robert Paquette, Sr to His Majesty, the King, has been executed and the consideration money, namely $50.00, should now be paid.

A protest has, however, been received from His Grace, the Archbishop of Montreal against the transfer being taken in the name of His Majesty, claiming that the title of the schoolhouse so removed and the property on which it is to be placed, should remain with the Church of England as at present.

Although negotiations for the removal of this school have been in progress for over a year, this is the first intimation the Department has received that the Church of England authorities were likely to raise any objection, although Mr Loiselle, the teacher, is also Church of England missionary there. The Department is paying for the site and the Indians are furnishing the money from their capital funds for the removal. There is a proviso, in the deed that the property shall so long as deemed expedient by the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs be occupied as a site for a Protestant Separate school for the said Band with remainder for the use of the said Band.
The only cause of complaint I can see that the Church would have is that they would, to a certain extent, lose control of the school, but as the Department pays the teacher's salary, I do not see that they would be very much out.

I am also doubtful whether an Indian on a reserve could sell direct to the Church of England without a surrender. The Law Clerk could decide this point if necessary.

Dear Sir:

You are doubtless aware of the fact that there is a little school here for the elementary education of the Protestant children of this Indian community, of which my husband, Mr. Andrew Emmett, has been in charge for the past five years.

It occurs to me that instruction in sewing, such as is given to the children who attend the Roman-Catholic school, should likewise be provided for the little girls of this Anglican parish, and I therefore think it advisable to offer my services as sewing instructress.

I am an expert needlewoman, and ready to follow any course of instruction which your Department might prescribe. For three lessons a week, each of an hour's duration, I should be satisfied with a remuneration of $10. a month throughout the school year.

May I add that, were such a monthly addition to our finances be forthcoming, the situation at home would be far less difficult for us. As we have two children to support, my husband's yearly salary of $600. is entirely insufficient to meet our needs.

Yours sincerely,

Alice Emmett.

Now, there remains the 25 feet between the convent and the boundary of the adjacent land, and the nuns consider that it is sufficient for the present to erect the proposed addition there.

As it is very important that the work should begin as soon as possible, in order to have it done before the opening of the classes this fall, I believe that it would be better to be content with the land that there is at present, as the nuns are satisfied on their part. Ottawa, November 30, 1927.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 24th instant, informing the Department that Miss Anna Capino will agree to the sale of the parcel of land which the Department desires to acquire for the use of St. Joseph's Academy, Pierreville. We note that she agrees to the sale of same for the sum of $300 and that she will remove the present building on this lot. Please inform Miss Capino that it is the intention of the Department to acquire this lot, and will allow her the sum of $300 therefor.

The Department will prepare a quit claim deed to be executed by Miss Capino, but, before doing so, it will be necessary to have a proper description of the plot of land by metes and bounds. You should state definitely the dimensions of this parcel of land, viz., width and length, starting at a point adjoining the present property of the Convent. This information should be forwarded as soon as possible, when the necessary documents will be prepared and forwarded to you for signature. You should also state how Miss Capino acquired this land from her aunt, and whether she is the sole owner and has the full right to dispose of same. As soon as the documents are signed by her payment of the purchase price of the land will be made.

Miss Capino may arrange to have the building on this land removed.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Memorandum to: Dr. W. H. Collins,
Director, Geological Survey,
Department of Mines.

Re: Embankment of the St. Francis River adjoining the school in the Indian village of Odanak, Yamaska county, Quebec.

The school at Odanak is situated on the top and about 40 feet from the edge of the embankment adjoining the northeast side of the St. Francis river (see Photographs 1 and 2). The embankment at this point is about 75 feet high and forms part of a spur delimited on the southeast and southwest sides by steep terraces which formed during the erosion of the river when it stood at a higher level. The abandoned channel of a former meander of the river to the north of the spur can be observed on the right in Photograph No. 3. A number of islands occur in the river below the spur and local inhabitants stated that the main channel which now passes to the east or right side of these formerly passed to the left or southwest side. The freshly cut banks at the base of the embankment on the northeast side of the river also indicates that the river is now eroding on that side. The material composing the bank is stratified marine clay which, because of its fine grain and soft character when wet, erodes very rapidly.

An examination of the embankment of the river adjoining the school shows that it is receding in two ways, (1) by surface water erosion and sliding at the top of the embankment, and (2) by erosion at the base of the embankment (by the river) especially at the time of spring flood.

(1) Surface erosion and sliding at top of embankment. The surface of the ground adjoining the school slopes gently to the top of the embankment so that in the spring and at times of heavy rain the surface water for a considerable area drains over the embankment at the rear of the school. An erosion gully, three or four feet deep and several feet wide, can be seen at this point. Considerable amounts of water also finds its way underground to this point, for water flows from the embankment in the spring and the Superior stated that at one time there was a well between the school and the top of the embankment. This water softens the clay causing it to slide.

(2) River erosion at the base of the embankment. As previously pointed out the river is now actively eroding the base of the embankment below the school. It is probable that this erosion is very slow when the water is low but must be considerable at time of flood when blocks of ice impinge on the soft clay banks. How long it will take for this action to endanger the school can only be determined by measurements of the embankment over a period of years.
Remedial Measures.

Although the school is not yet endangered it is evident that it will be endangered in a very few years if the erosion and slumping at the top of the embankment continues. To prevent this steps should be taken to drain away all or as much as possible of the surface water from the territory adjoining the school and if necessary any water from the roadway that finds its way on the embankment across the school yard. If this is accomplished it will not only prevent surface erosion but the penetration of water to the embankment underground where it softens the clay and facilitates slumping. There is a gully crossing the road a few hundred feet south of the school to which it would probably not be difficult to drain the surface water from the school area and from the road opposite the school. It will be also necessary to fill in the erosion gully that has formed to the rear of the school. The top of the embankment opposite the school is now protected by posts and boards and it may be advisable to continue this southeastward if erosion furrows continue to cut down the edge of the embankment. The Supervisor stated that formerly the embankment was covered with trees, a few of which remain. If more of these were planted they would no doubt assist considerably in preventing slumping.

The remedial measures that should be taken to prevent erosion at the base of the embankment is an engineering rather than geological problem. There are at least three ways in which it may be prevented: by driving piles, by a network of mats cement blocks*, or by a concrete wall. Which of these methods should be used or whether they should be used at all will depend, of course, on the cost. It is possible that it may be cheaper eventually to move the school than go to this expense. Steps are taken to prevent the erosion of the bank by the river; the protection should cover the cut bank on the upper (southeast) side of the school as well as directly below the school and should be as high as the high water level of the river.

Respectfully submitted,

M. E. Wilson.

*See reports of Mississippi River Commission, Washington.

Memorandum:

Dr. Scott,

Prices were invited by Indian Agent Maurault from local contractors for the construction of a reinforced concrete wall on one side of the school lot at Odanak, along the bank of the St. Francis River, which is gradually being damaged by erosion, as mentioned in my memorandum of May 9th last, turned out hereunder.

The estimated cost of this work, according to my memorandum of the 9th of May, amounts to $4050.00. In view of the fact, however, that a pile driving apparatus will have to be secured from Jorel at an expensive price, there being no such apparatus in the locality, I feel to recommend that Mr. Desroches' tender be accepted, and that he be authorized to proceed with the work as early as possible, in order that it may be completed before the cold season sets in.

As the greatest amount of the work will consist in the laying of concrete, I would suggest that an inspector be appointed to supervise this part of the work only, and that I be furnished with the name of a person to act as Inspector.

In reply to your letter of the 17th August No. 32040, I must say I have inspected the retaining wall at the St. Joseph Convent at Odanak with Mr. Chas. Ed. Desrochers the builder of the said wall.

We found a crack in only one place in the wall, at the same place where such crack was noticed almost immediately after construction. The remainder of the wall is in perfect state. Memorandum: Mr. Williams,

As previously mentioned in my memorandum of the 4th of September, 1931, the reinforced concrete retaining wall which was erected by the Department in 1930 in front of the School lot at the Abenakis Reserve Convent, along the St. Francis river is exposed to serious damage on account of underground springs which seep through the filling behind this wall, and which were not noticeable at the time of its construction.

In order to prevent the wall from being undermined or damaged by erosion or otherwise, the Department, last December authorized the contractor who had charge of the construction of this wall to carry out additional drainage and to construct a number of concrete buttresses in front of the wall, but owing to the lateness of the season only a small portion of the work authorized was performed. The Department is now advised by Indian Agent Maurault that the springs have almost ruined the foundation of this retaining wall, and he advises that some protection work should be undertaken at once to prevent it from being damaged beyond repair. It is also suggested by him that an Engineer be sent as soon as possible to make inspection of the present condition of the wall, in order to decide on the most effective and permanent way of putting it in a safe state of repair.

If you approve of the above mentioned suggestion I shall arrange to proceed with this inspection work at the beginning of next week.

Sir:

I beg to submit the following report on conditions at Pierreville, Que.

While at Pierreville, Mr. William Watson asked me if I would attend a meeting of the Indians at night as they had some matters they desired to place before me. As he called on me with the Chief I consented to do so. Mr. Watson spoke, but evidently dealt with only matters which he had recently been taking up with the department when at Ottawa. It may be as well to place a summary of his remarks on file.

He first spoke of the concrete wall, constructed about two years ago back of the school, stating that it had cost $4600.00 and was now falling down. I may say that I inspected this wall myself and found it to be in a very dangerous condition and liable to fail at any time. This is evidently due to imperfect drainage and possibly insufficient foundation. As it now stands it is a menace and liable to cause loss of life. If immediate renewal is not possible, owing to lack of funds, I suggest that the area be temporarily fenced off and warning signs placed in conspicuous places. I think that it is a matter which the Departmental Engineer should look into.

C. C. Parker.
Inspector.
Memorandum

Mr. Williams,

As authorized I last week made an inspection of the reinforced concrete retaining wall, which was erected by the Department in 1930, in front of the school lot along the St. Francis River at Odanak, on the Abenaki reserve. The wall referred to in my memorandum of June 4th hereunder, and I urge to make the following suggestions in order to prevent this wall from suffering from further damages, as well as the school property:

1. Grading of the playground behind the School to prevent surface water from accumulating around the school buildings, and draining down the embankment towards the rear of the retaining wall causing erosion of the embankment and undermining the foundation of the wall.

2. Construction of a culley 24" diameter at the lowest point in the school yard, also the laying of 18" drain from this culley as far as the bottom of the embankment or river shore.

3. Installation of an eave trough in the rear of the laundry building with connection to the above mentioned culley.

4. Laying of two rows of "U" drain tile in the rear along the retaining wall as an additional means of taking care of the surface running down the embankment.

5. Erection of a small concrete curb between the laundry building and the fence of the school lot on the east side to prevent any water from running down the embankment after heavy storms.

6. Filling of the cavities which have been formed by erosion at certain places on the embankment behind the retaining wall, using the earth from the grading of the school grounds.

7. Filling of the cracks which have appeared in the wall.

8. Construction of large reinforced concrete buttresses in front of the wall to strengthen it, more particularly on the east corner and the centre.

The above mentioned repairs could be carried out either by day labour or by contract, as a means of relief to the Indians who are...
without any means whatever of earning anything, there being large amounts paid every month for relief.

I would suggest, with your approval that I be authorized to obtain approximate estimates of the cost of the above mentioned work from some of the local builders before making any further recommendations in connection with this matter.

July 29, 1932.

Mr. Williams,

With reference to the repairs required to the reinforced concrete wall in front of the school lot along the St. Francis River at Odanak, on the Abenakis Reserve, also the drainage and levelling of the ground in order to prevent the wall and the government school property from being further damaged, I beg to say that the Department is now in receipt of some estimates of the cost of the work, which prices I consider altogether too high. I would suggest, therefore, that only the most important and necessary work be carried out for the present by day labour under the supervision of a white foreman, employing Indian labour, with the understanding that the cost of the work is to be paid for from the appropriation for Miller. The works which I would suggest being carried out this year are as follows:

1. Grading of the playground behind the school to prevent the surface water from accumulating around the school building, and draining down the embankment towards the rear of the retaining wall causing erosion of the embankment and undermining the foundation of the wall.

2. Construction of a gulley 24" diameter, at the lowest point in the school yard, also laying of 12" drain from this gulley as far as the bottom of the embankment on the river shore, unless permission can be obtained to excavate an open ditch on the dividing line of the lot, which of course would be much cheaper.

3. Building of a 6" eave trough, galvanized iron, in the rear of the laundry building with connection to the above mentioned gulley, with 6" vitrified drain pipe.

4. Filling of the cavities which have been formed by erosion at certain places on the embankment behind the retaining wall, using earth from the grading of the school grounds.

5. Construction of two reinforced concrete buttresses in front of the wall, one on the east end corner, and one in the centre where two cracks are located, these buttresses to be 3 feet thick from top to bottom of the wall, 5 feet in length at the top sloping down to a length of 10 feet at the base, with a slope of 45 deg., approximately. The buttresses to be reinforced with steel from the fence on top of the wall.
The total cost of the above mentioned work is about $1500.00.

Should you approve of this work being carried out it would be of relief to the Indians who are practically without any means of sustenance at the present time. I would ask you to kindly give me the name of a competent white foreman to supervise the work, should you approve.

April 22, 1933.

Memorandum:

Dr. McGill,

Mr. MacKenzie.

The Department was advised yesterday by the Superior of the Abenakis School Convent at Odanak, Que., while in this office, that the concrete retaining wall in front of the School lot on the Abenakis Reserve along the St. Francis River, referred to in a memorandum dated June 4, 1932, turned out hereunder, had been partly washed away by landslides which occurred at the beginning of this week on the embankment at the back of the Convent.

According to information given by the Superior the balance of the wall is liable to also be washed down, on account of the exceedingly high water in the St. Francis River, and the erosion of the banks, etc. The teachers as well as the parents of the pupils are quite alarmed over the danger of the building being damaged through the occurrence of further landslides. It was considered advisable, therefore, to ask the teachers, through the Superior, not to allow anyone in the building until further instructions had been given by the Department.

In view of these facts I would suggest that Mr. Chene be requested to proceed to Odanak next week, upon his visit to Saguenay, to examine the situation and advise the Department as to what should be done for the protection of the building. I would also ask that this officer be allowed to instruct the School authorities to temporarily close the School should he find that the conditions warrant this action, and until he has had time to furnish the Department with a report on his investigation.

Should these suggestions meet with your approval I will confirm the instructions already given.

Memorandum

Dr. McGill.

In accordance with your approval on Mr. Sutherland's memorandum of the 22nd ultimo, hereunder, I made on the 25th of April an inspection of the concrete retaining wall along the shore of the St. Francis River, in front of the School property at Odanak, which has been partly demolished, and I beg to give you the following information as to its present condition.

The portion of the wall which has been completely over-turned and washed down into the river is 34 feet long, starting from its west end. The earth filling, which had been placed behind this part of the wall for the grading of the embankment also slipped away covering the wall underneath the water. There is still a length of 26 feet of wall next to that demolished that is partly over-turned, and will have to be torn down owing to its dangerous condition. The rest of the wall, a length of 68 feet, which is the portion opposite the school building, is still in its original position and appears to be firmly secured in place, which means that it will continue to serve the purpose for which it was erected.

From observations made while on the ground it seems to me that the main cause of the damages above mentioned are due to the fact that the foundation or concrete base has been gradually undermined by underground springs which run between a layer of marine sand forming the top of the embankment and a bed of clay underneath. The surface water running down the embankment from the school property, which is exceptionally great at certain periods of the year, also contributed to the undermining of the foundation of the wall. I would strongly recommend that the following works be authorized as early as possible, in order to ensure proper drainage of the school lot, protection of the remaining portion of the wall, and the improvement and grading of the embankment where the land slide occurred.

DRAINAGE OF SCHOOL LOT.

Construction of gulley on the south side of Notre Dame road in line with the road leading to the school, this gulley to be connected to the main sewer pipe on the main road.
Construction of two gullies at low points in the school grounds to be connected to a main drain pipe placed along the east side of the school lot, as far as the bottom of the embankment or river shore.

Erection of a small concrete curb between the laundry building and the fence of the school lot on the east side to prevent water from running down the embankment after heavy storms or in the spring season.

Placing of 4" eave troughing in the rear of laundry building with connection to the above mentioned drain pipe.

PROTECTION OF EXISTING WALL.

Demolishing portion of wall partly over-turned.

Construction of two reinforced concrete buttresses one on the east end corner and one at the centre.

Filling of cavities which have been formed by erosion of the embankment behind the retaining wall, also grading of portion of embankment where the wall has been demolished, so as to give it a regular slope.

Placing of layer of large boulders at the base of embankment on top of the clay bed where the above mentioned grading is to be done, and the sowing of entire embankment with grass seed.

Erection of a fence at top of the embankment between laundry building and the eastern boundary of the lot as protection to the school children.

The above mentioned work will cost about $1,800 and could be carried out by day labour under the supervision of a white foreman as a relief measure to the Indians of Odanak, who are mostly all receiving assistance from the Department. If this meets with your approval, I would ask to be furnished with the name of a white foreman, in order that the work may be proceeded with as soon as ground conditions will permit.

DEPARTMENTAL ENGINEER.

PROJECTS TO BE CARRIED OUT ON ABEBAKIS SCHOOL PROPERTY.

1. The length of concrete wall, namely 24 feet, which is partly overturned shall be torn down with all possible care in order to avoid accidents and sliding of the earth behind it.

2. Filling of the cavities which have been formed by erosion of the embankment behind the retaining wall, also grading of portion of embankment where the wall has been demolished so as to give it a regular and natural slope.

3. Erection of a wire fence at the top of the embankment in line with the laundry building and the east boundary of the lot. This fence to be similar to that around the school property.

4. Construction of two gullies at the lowest points in the school yard to be connected to the main drain pipe which will be placed along the east side of the school lot and continued downward as far as the bottom of the embankment leading to the river shore. The gullies are to be made of 18" vitrified or cement pipes provided with standard cast iron perforated grates or covers, adjusted on concrete base, with a wide cement border all around, built in such a manner as to prevent the admission of earth, etc.

Connection pipe from the gullies to the main drain is to be made of 9" vitrified drain pipe, which should connect to the gully at least 18" above the bottom to provide for its cleaning from time to time.

The main drain pipe above mentioned from the yard to the river, on a length of about 125 feet to be made of 18" vitrified sewer pipe with necessary T-connections for the gullies. This main pipe should be given an adequate slope in order to ensure easy drainage of the water from the gullies to its outlet.

A manhole should be constructed where the main drain pipe begins in the school yard made of concrete with cast iron or steel cover. The portion of this main drain down the embankment to the river shore on a length of about 100 feet should be made of 18" corrugated steel pipe instead of the vitrified clay pipe, all of which should be well secured together and to the bottom of the trench. A concrete box shall be placed where these two different kinds of pipe converge together.
5. Erection of small concrete curb between the laundry building and the fence of the school lot on the east side to prevent water from running down the embankment after heavy storms, or in the spring season. This curb to be 9 inches thick and about three feet high.

6. Placing of 4" galv. iron sewer-troughing in the rear of the laundry building, with connection to empty into one of the existing gullies.

7. Construction of reinforced concrete buttress on the east end corner of the reinforced concrete retaining wall similar to the existing one.

8. Repairing of the drain pipe from the roof of the building.
I would ask you, therefore, to convey this information to the Mayor of Ste Lucie for the information of his Council.

Yours very truly,
